These are the lists of entries of '''[[2018 BWF World Championships]]''' qualification. == Overview == === Events === This event holds men's singles and doubles, women's singles and doubles, and mixed doubles. === Number of players/member association quota === This event's total limit of eligibility players is 400 players, the following charts are the rules and the distribution.{{cite web|title=Regulations for Eligibility and Processing of Entries for World Championships|url=http://system.bwf.website/documents/folder_1_81/Regulations/Major-Events/Part%20III%20-%20Section%207B%20-%20Regulation%20For%20Eligibility%20&%20Processing%20of%20Entries%20for%20World%20Championships.pdf|publisher=BWF|accessdate=28 June 2018}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! width="150" | ! width="150" | Men's singles ! width="150" | Women's singles ! width="150" | Men's doubles ! width="150" | Women's doubles ! width="150" | Mixed doubles ! width="150" | Total |- ! {{Infobox film | name = Alive: 20 Years Later | image = | writer = | starring = | director = Jill Fullerton-Smith | producer = Jill Fullerton-Smith | narrator = [[Martin Sheen]] | cinematography = | distributor = [[Touchstone Home Video]] | released = {{Film date|1993}} | runtime = 51 minutes | language = [[English language|English]]
[[Spanish language|Spanish]] | budget = }} '''''Alive: 20 Years Later''''' is a 1993 [[documentary film]] produced, directed and written by Jill Fullerton-Smith and narrated by [[Martin Sheen]]. ==Content== The documentary focused on the lives (20 years later) of the 16 [[Uruguay]]an survivors of the [[Accidents and incidents in aviation|airplane crash]] of [[Uruguayan Air Force Flight 571]], which crashed into the [[Andes mountains]] on October 13, 1972. It also discussed their participation in the production of the 1993 feature film ''[[Alive (1993 film)|Alive: The Miracle of the Andes]]''. ==Format== The documentary was released as a companion to ''Alive: The Miracle of the Andes''. It is also included as an extra on the DVD of the 30th Anniversary Edition of ''Alive: The Miracle of the Andes''. ==See also== *[[Nando Parrado]] *[[Piers Paul Read]] *''[[Alive: The Story of the Andes Survivors]]'' *''[[Miracle in the Andes: 72 Days on the Mountain and My Long Trek Home]]'' == External links == * {{IMDb title|0206544|Alive: 20 Years Later}} {{1972 Andes flight disaster}} [[Category:1993 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American aviation films]] [[Category:Documentary films about aviation accidents or incidents]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Rugby union films]] [[Category:1972 Andes flight disaster]] [[Category:1990s documentary films]] [[Category:Films about aviation accidents or incidents]] [[Category:Works about cannibalism]] {{hist-documentary-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{peacock|date=March 2018}}{{Distinguish|Caspian tiger}} '''Anatolian Tigers''' ({{lang-tr|Anadolu Kaplanları}}) is a term internationally used in the context of the [[Turkish economy]] to refer to and to explain the [[phenomenon]] of a number of cities in [[Turkey]] which have displayed impressive growth records since the 1980s, as well as to a defined new breed of entrepreneurs rising in prominence and who can often be traced back to the cities in question and who generally rose from the status of [[Small and medium enterprises|SMEs]].{{cite journal |title=Anatolian Tigers or Islamic Capital: Prospects and Challenges |first1=Ömer |last1=Demir |first2=Mustafa |last2=Acar |first3=Metin |last3=Toprak |journal=Middle Eastern Studies |volume=40 |date=2004 |issue=6 |pages = 166–188|doi=10.1080/0026320042000282937}} Where particular cities are concerned, the term is most often used for the capitals or depending centers of [[Denizli]], [[Gaziantep]], [[Kayseri]], [[Bursa]], [[Konya]], [[Kocaeli Province|Kocaeli]], [[Kahramanmaraş]].{{cite web | url= http://mondediplo.com/1997/07/turkey | title = New Faces of Islam|author =Wendy Christianasen|publisher=[[Le Monde Diplomatique]]| accessdate=1997-07| date = July 1997}} Within Turkey, the accent is laid on cities that have received little state investments or subsidies over the years. [[Çorum]], [[Denizli]], [[Gaziantep]] and [[Kahramanmaraş]], in particular, are cited among the cities who "made it themselves". In time order, while Denizli in Turkey's [[Aegean Region, Turkey|Aegean Region]] was the early hour precursor for rapid growth in an Anatolian Tiger pattern,{{cite web | url = http://wz.uni.lodz.pl/ersa/abstr/ozgur_p.pdf |work=18th European Advanced Studies Institute in Regional Science |title=Integration of a Local Economy to the Global and European Markets through Export–Led Growth and Specialized Textile Products Export: Home Textile Production in Denizli – Turkey |author=Hüseyin Özgür |publisher=[[University of Lodz]] |access-date=2007-04-18}} [[Gaziantep]], [[Malatya]], [[Konya]] and [[Kayseri]] are the most recently cited prominent Tigers on the basis of the number of companies they have among Turkey's 500 biggest.{{cite web | url= http://search.ft.com/iab?queryText=Konya&id=061120005054&location=http%3A%2F%2Fsearch.ft.com%2FftArticle%3FqueryText%3DKonya%26id%3D061120005054&referer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com.tr%2Fsearch%3Fq%3D%22anatolian+tigers%22 | title= Anatolian Tigers: Regions prove plentiful | author= Pelin Turgut | publisher= [[Financial Times]] | accessdate= 2006-11-20 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090820000758/http://search.ft.com/iab?queryText=Konya&id=061120005054&location=http%3A%2F%2Fsearch.ft.com%2FftArticle%3FqueryText%3DKonya%26id%3D061120005054&referer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com.tr%2Fsearch%3Fq%3D%22anatolian+tigers%22 | archive-date= 2009-08-20 | dead-url= yes | df= }} These largest are the forerunners of further large companies and a multitude of smaller ones. Aside from their production units, the definition generally excludes companies who have their headquarters in the largest cities of Turkey; namely [[İstanbul]], [[Ankara]], [[İzmir]], [[Bursa]] and [[Adana]], as well as companies constituted with public capital. The term is also echoed, in the form "Anatolian Lions" (Turkish: ''Anadolu Aslanları''), by the name of the private sector association [http://www.askon.org.tr Askon] that brings together businessmen from a number of other cities who have found common grounds between each other. This association has branches in [[Ankara]], [[Burdur]], [[Bursa]], [[Gebze]], [[İzmit]], [[Konya]], [[Malatya]] and [[Trabzon]]. These lions are less often cited among the tigers for several reasons. Other variations of the term, such "Turkey's Tigers" or "Turkish Tigers", as used by the [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] without excluding the most commonly used form of "Anatolian Tigers" have also been pronounced.{{cite web | url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/wideangle/shows/turkey/filmmaker.html |title = Wide Angle: Turkey's Tigers|author1=Jon Alpert |author2=Matthew O'Neill |work=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]| accessdate=2007-04-22}}{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/discussion/2006/08/15/DI2006081500692.html?nav=rss_business/international |title=Wide Angle: Turkey's Tigers|author1=Jon Alpert |author2=Matthew O'Neill |newspaper=[[Washington Post]]| accessdate=2006-08-23 | date=2006-08-23}} {| class="wikitable floatright" !City !!Nr. of companies {{Alternating rows table section|es=background:#e5e5e5 | {{!}}[[Denizli]] {{!!}}29 | {{!}}[[Gaziantep]] & [[Kayseri]] {{!!}}23 | {{!}}[[Balıkesir]] {{!!}}15 | {{!}}[[Konya]] {{!!}}14 | {{!}}[[Kahramanmaraş]] {{!!}}9 | {{!}}[[Ordu]] {{!!}}7 | {{!}}[[Samsun]] {{!!}}5 | {{!}}[[Çorum]] {{!!}}8 | {{!}}[[Trabzon]] & [[Ünye]] {{!!}}4 | {{!}}[[Kütahya]] & [[Niğde]] {{!!}}3 | {{!}}[[Adıyaman]] & [[Afyonkarahisar]]
& [[Çankırı]] & [[Giresun]]
& [[Isparta]] & [[Karaman]]
& [[Malatya]] {{!!}}2 }} |} Beyond their shared characteristics in an economical perspective, references have also been made, especially in international media, to different political connotations within the term, including by associating this capital with [[Islam]]ic values or extending its whole under such definitions as "Islamic capital" or "green capital". The political choices and the voting trends of the cities and of particulars in question may differ widely between each other. A 2005 study by the [http://www.esiweb.org European Stability Initiative] that was focused on [[Kayseri]] uses the term "Islamic [[Calvinists]]" to define the entrepreneurs and their values.{{cite web | url=http://www.esiweb.org/pdf/esi_document_id_69.pdf |title=Islamic Calvinists: Change and Conservatism in Central Anatolia |author =ESI |work=European Stability Initiative, Berlin |accessdate=2005-09-19}} Several business awards or conferences in Turkey draw reference from the term "Anatolian Tigers" or its variants. The term was copied after the ''[[Four Asian Tigers|Asian Tigers]]''. ==Geographical distribution== According to the 2005 Istanbul Chamber of Industry's annual ranking of Turkey's top 1000 industrial enterprises,[http://www2.iso.org.tr/en/index.asp Istanbul Chamber of Industry] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070427134015/http://www2.iso.org.tr/en/index.asp |date=2007-04-27 }} the adjacent table contains cities which best fit the definition of Anatolian Tigers.[http://www2.iso.org.tr/en/500buyuk_Default.asp Istanbul Chamber of Industry: Turkey's Top 1000 Industrial Enterprises] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070423020204/http://www2.iso.org.tr/en/500buyuk_Default.asp |date=2007-04-23 }}. The table excludes the [[Thrace]]-[[İstanbul]]-[[Bursa]]-[[Eskişehir]]-[[Ankara]] axis, the highly integrated [[İzmir]]-[[Manisa]]-[[Aydın]] and [[Çukurova]] regions, as well as the Turkish coastline until the [[coal]] basin in the western [[Black Sea Region, Turkey|Black Sea Region]]. [[Southeastern Anatolia Project]] region, included in the count, currently displays only the first signs of its potential industrial might. Likewise, the recent opening of continuous highway along the [[Black Sea]] coast is expected to deeply influence the fortunes of the region along the shoreline. Aside those mentioned in the table, the urban centers who to date have one company that is represented among Turkey's top 1000 were: [[Bafra]], [[Bucak, Burdur|Bucak]], [[Bulancak]], [[Çarşamba]], [[Çorum]], [[Diyarbakır]], [[Elazığ]], [[Erzurum]], [[İnebolu]], [[Kars]], [[Kastamonu]], [[Kırşehir]], [[Mardin]], [[Rize]], [[Siirt]], [[Sivas]], [[Suluova]], [[Tokat]] and [[Yozgat]]. Among these cities [[Trabzon]] has one company in top 25. ==See also== * [[Economy of Turkey]] * [[Tiger economy]] * [[Tiger Cub Economies]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.askon.org.tr Association of Businessmen of Anatolian Lions] [[Category:Tiger economies]] [[Category:Economy of Turkey]] [[Category:Economic booms]]

{{Infobox military conflict |image= [[Image:BattleOfLakeRegillus.jpg|right|300px]] |caption= [[Dioscuri|Castor and Pollux]] fighting at the Battle of Lake Regillus, 1880 illustration by [[John Reinhard Weguelin]] to the [[Lays of Ancient Rome]] by [[Thomas Macaulay]] |conflict=Battle of Lake Regillus |partof=the [[Roman-Latin wars]] |date=c. 496 BC |place=near [[Frascati]] ([[Rome]]) |result=Decisive Roman victory End of Tarquinian attempts to retake the Roman throne |combatant1=[[Roman Republic]] |combatant2=[[Latin League]] |commander1=[[Aulus Postumius Albus Regillensis|Aulus Postumius Albus]],
[[Titus Aebutius Elva]] (master of the horse) |commander2=[[Octavius Mamilius]] †,
[[Tarquinius Superbus]] |strength1= |strength2= |casualties1= |casualties2= }} {{Campaignbox Latin Wars}} {{Campaignbox First Latin War}} [[Image:Lake regillus.jpg|thumb|right|250 px|An engraving of Lake Regillus, where the battle took place.]] [[Image:Prataporci site Img 020.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Prataporci site, where the battle took place, view from [[Monte Porzio Catone]]]] {{Campaignbox Rome's Early Italian Campaigns}} {{wikisource|Lays of Ancient Rome/The Battle of the Lake Regillus|Macaulay's The Battle of the Lake Regillus}} The '''Battle of Lake Regillus''' was a legendary Roman victory over the [[Latin League]] shortly after the establishment of the [[Roman Republic]] and as part of a wider [[Latin War (498–493 BC)|Latin War]]. The Latins were led by an elderly [[Lucius Tarquinius Superbus]], the seventh and last [[King of Rome]], who had been expelled in 509 BC, and his son-in-law, [[Octavius Mamilius]], the dictator of [[Tusculum]]. The battle marked the final attempt of the Tarquins to reclaim their throne. According to legend, [[Castor and Pollux]] fought on the side of the Romans.Grant,'' The History of Rome'', p. 37 ==Background== The threat of invasion by Rome's former allies in Latium led to the appointment of [[Aulus Postumius Albus Regillensis|Aulus Postumius Albus]] as [[Roman dictator|dictator]]. The year in which the battle occurred is unclear, and has been since ancient times. Livy places the battle in 499 BC, but says some of his sources also suggest the battle occurred during Postumius' consulship in 496 BC.[[Livy]], ''[[Ab urbe condita libri (Livy)|Ab urbe condita]]'', [[s:From the Founding of the City/Book 2#19|2.19-21]]Sinnigen, William G and Boak, Arthur E R, A History of Rome to AD 565, 6th ed,1977, p. 46 The other major source for this historical period, [[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]] Dion. Hal. 1.66 Retrieved from http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Dionysius_of_Halicarnassus/1C*.html also places the battle in 496 BC.Cornell, ''The Beginnings of Rome'', p. 216 Modern authors have also suggested 493 BC''[[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology]]'', [[William Smith (lexicographer)|William Smith]], Editor or 489 BC. Lake Regillus was located in the relic of a volcanic crater between Rome and Tusculum. The lake was drained in the fourth century BC.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} According to Livy, the [[Volsci]] (a neighbouring tribe to the south of Latium) had raised troops to send to the aid of the Latins against Rome, however the haste of the Roman dictator in joining battle meant that the Volscian forces did not arrive in time.[[Livy]], ''[[Ab urbe condita libri (Livy)|Ab urbe condita]]'', [[s:From the Founding of the City/Book 2#22|2.22]] ==Battle== The dictator Postumius led the Roman infantry, while [[Titus Aebutius Elva]] was [[Master of the Horse#Magister Equitum (Ancient Rome)|Master of the Horse]]. Tarquin was accompanied by his eldest and last remaining son, [[Titus Tarquinius|Titus]]. It was said that the presence of the Tarquinii caused the Romans to fight more passionately than in any previous battle. Early in the battle, the king was injured attacking Postumius. The magister equitum charged at Mamilius, and both were wounded: Aebutius in the arm, and the Latin dictator in the chest. The magister equitum had to withdraw from the field, and direct his troops from a distance. The king's soldiers, including many exiled Romans, began to overpower the republican forces, and the Romans suffered a setback when [[Marcus Valerius Volusus]] (consul in 505 BC) was killed by a spear while attacking Titus Tarquinius, but Postumius brought fresh troops from his own bodyguard, and halted the exiles' progress. Meanwhile, [[Titus Herminius Aquilinus]], who had won fame fighting alongside [[Horatius Cocles|Horatius]] at the [[Pons Sublicius#Horatius Cocles at the bridge|Sublician bridge]], and served as consul in 506 BC, engaged Mamilius and slew him; but while attempting to strip his fallen enemy and claim the spoils, Herminius was killed by a javelin. As the outcome of the battle seemed in doubt, Postumius ordered the cavalry to dismount and attack on foot, forcing the Latins to retreat and capturing the Latin camp. Tarquin and the Latin army abandoned the field, resulting in a decisive Roman victory. Postumius returned to Rome with his army, and celebrated a triumph.Livy, ''[[Ab urbe condita libri (Livy)|Ab Urbe Condita]]'' [[s:From the Founding of the City/Book 2#19|2.19-20]][[Fasti Triumphales]] A popular legend reported that the [[Dioscuri]], Castor and Pollux, fought alongside the Romans, transfigured as two young horsemen. Postumius ordered a [[Temple of Castor and Pollux|temple]] built in their honour in the [[Roman Forum]], in the place where they had watered their horses. In the nineteenth century, the battle was celebrated in [[Thomas Macaulay|Thomas Macaulay's]] ''[[Lays of Ancient Rome]]''. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== ;Primary sources *{{cite wikisource|title=From the Founding of the City|author=Livy|others=trans. Canon Roberts|year=1905}} (print: ''Book 1 as The Rise of Rome, [[Oxford University Press]], 1998, {{ISBN|0-19-282296-9}}'') ;Secondary sources *{{cite book|authorlink=Michael Grant (author)|last=Grant|first=Michael|title=The History of Rome|publisher= [[Faber and Faber]]|year=1993|isbn=0-571-11461-X}} *[[Livy]]: [[Ab Urbe Condita Libri (Livy)|Ab urbe condita]] [[s:From the Founding of the City/Book 2#19|Book II cap. 19]]; [[s:From the Founding of the City/Book 2#20|20]]. *[http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/liv.html Ab Urbe Condita (Latin)] *[http://www.theotherpages.org/poems/regillus.html ''The Battle of Lake Regillus''] poem from Macaulay's "Lays of Ancient Rome". *Cornell, Tim, ''The Beginnings of Rome: Italy and Rome from the Bronze Age to the Punic Wars, C.1000-263 BC'', Routledge, 1995. {{ISBN|0-415-01596-0}}. {{Ancient Roman Wars}} {{coord|41|52|55|N|12|41|50|E|region:IT_type:landmark_source:kolossus-rowiki|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Battle Of Lake Regillus}} [[Category:490s BC conflicts]] [[Category:496 BC]] [[Category:Battles involving the Roman Republic|Lake Regillus]] [[Category:500s BC]] [[Category:490s BC]] [[Category:5th century BC in the Roman Republic]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Infobox civil conflict |partof = the [[anti-austerity protests]] | image = Blockupy 2013 Deportation Airport3.jpg | caption = A Blockupy protest at [[Frankfurt Airport]] in 2013. | place = Primarily [[Frankfurt-am-Main]], with some actions across [[Germany]] | coordinates = | causes = [[Economic inequality|Economic]] and [[social inequality]], [[Big Business#Influence over government|corporate influence over government]], ''inter alia''. | status = | goals = * Rejection of [[austerity]] by [[European Central Bank]] * [[Anti-capitalism|Anti-capitalist]] and [[anti-globalization]] social change * An end to [[deportation]] and anti-immigration border control | result = | methods = * [[Occupation (protest)|Occupation]] * [[Non violent protest]] * [[Civil disobedience]] * [[Picketing (protest)|Picketing]] * [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]] * [[Direct action]] | side1= * [[Association for the Taxation of Financial Transactions and for Citizens' Action|ATTAC]] * [[The Left (Germany)|Die Linke]] * [[Syriza]] * [[Vereinte Dienstleistungsgewerkschaft|Verdi]] and other [[Trade unions in Germany|German trade unions]] * Local [[Socialism|socialist]], [[Communism|communist]], [[Anarchism|anarchist]] and [[Anti-fascism|antifa]] groups | side2= * [[Hesse State Police]], including ''Wachpolizei'' units * [[Federal Police (Germany)|Bundespolizei]] * [[Bereitschaftspolizei]] units from the aforementioned police forces | side3= | notes =[https://blockupy.org/en/ Official Website] }} '''Blockupy''' is a [[Social movement|movement]] protesting against [[austerity]]. The Blockupy alliance includes trade unions and Germany's [[The Left (Germany)|''Linkspartei'']].<ref name="guardian-18032015"/>
Representing grass-roots critics of supranational financial institutions such as the “troika”: the [[European Commission]] (EC), [[European Central Bank]] (ECB) and [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF),<ref name="scmp-18032015"/> its name is derived from the [[Occupy movement]] which sprang up in [[Wall Street]] in 2011.<ref name="scmp-18032015"/>
Organisers have verbally supported (since July 2015, former) Greek finance minister [[Yanis Varoufakis]]'s criticism that ECB policy towards Athens is “asphyxiating”.<ref name="scmp-18032015"/>
==History== [[File:DIE LINKE vor Ort bei den Blockupy-Protesten vom 16. bis 19. Mai 2012 in Frankfurt am Main (7220851362).jpg|thumb|A Blockupy protest outside the then-current [[European Central Bank]] building in 2012.|left]] Thousands of people attended the first demonstration in [[Frankfurt]] in 2012.<ref name="bbc-18032015">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-31938592|title=Germany riot targets new ECB headquarters in Frankfurt|work=BBC News|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2013, protests in Frankfurt were met with heavy police violence. A peaceful demonstration was stopped, 1000 protesters were kettled for hours, and hundreds were injured, several severely.<ref> http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/frankfurt-schwerverletzte-bei-blockupy-demonstration-12204307.html </ref> Police action was criticized heavily afterward nationally<ref> http://www.fr.de/frankfurt/dossier/dossier/blockupy-frankfurt/blockupy-demo-entsetzen-ueber-polizei-kessel-a-701904 </ref> and internationally.<ref> http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/blockupy-demo-in-frankfurt-osze-kritisiert-polizeigewalt-gegen-journalisten-1.1690723 </ref>
===European Central Bank opening=== [[File:EZB Protest (16234852703).jpg|thumb|Police car burned down during Blockupy movement protests, 18 March 2015.|left]] On 18 March 2015, the day of the opening of the [[Seat of the European Central Bank]], Blockupy organized a major protest in Frankfurt attended by between 17,000 and 20,000 people from Germany and other parts of Europe, including 10,000 people at the main rally.<ref name="scmp-18032015">{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/1741249/blockupy-protesters-clash-police-new-ecb-headquarters-frankfurt|title=‘Blockupy’ protesters clash with police at new ECB headquarters in Frankfurt|work=SCMP|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="reuters-15032015">{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/03/15/uk-ecb-protest-idUKKBN0MB0HR20150315|title=Thousands to protest in Frankfurt against ECB 'austerity'|work=Reuters|date=15 March 2015|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="hr-170000">{{cite news|url=http://www.hr-online.de/website/rubriken/nachrichten/indexhessen34938.jsp?rubrik=91009&key=standard_document_54812349|title=17.000 demonstrieren gegen EZB|work=Hessischer Rundfunk|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> The Seat of the European Central Bank, the ECB's new headquarters, was selected as the venue for the demonstration so as to highlight the contradiction between the ECB's lavish spending on its own US$1.4-billion building while forcing cuts and market reforms on countries like [[Greece]] and [[Cyprus]].<ref name="guardian-18032015"/><ref name="scmp-18032015"/><ref name="reuters-15032015"/> Ulrich Wilken, an organiser, said: “Our protest is against the ECB, as a member of the troika, that, despite the fact that it is not democratically elected, hinders the work of the Greek government. We want the austerity politics to end.”<ref name="guardian-18032015"/> The pan-European protests included members of Greece's radical left governing party [[Syriza]] and Spain's anti-corruption [[Podemos (Spanish political party)|Podemos]].<ref name="bbc-18032015"/>
[[File:Miguel Urbán Frankfurt Blockupy 2015 11.JPG|thumb|right|Miguel Urbán talking at the Römerberg Blockupy event.]] The day included both peaceful protest and violent direct action. 10,000 people met at [[Römerberg (Frankfurt)|Römerberg]], where speakers included [[Sahra Wagenknecht]] from the ''Linkspartei'', [[anti-globalization|globalization critic]] [[Naomi Klein]], comedian [[Urban Priol]], Giorgios Chondros from Syriza and Miguel Urbán from Podemos.<ref>[https://blockupy.org/5716/blockupy-kundgebung-mit-naomi-klein-sarah-wagenknecht-und-urban-priol-zusagen-auch-von-podemos-und-syriza-zahlreiche-initiativen-dabei/ Blockupy Kundgebung mit Naomi Klein, Sarah Wagenknecht und Urban Priol zusagen auch von Podemos und Syriza zahlreiche Initiativen dabei], Blockupy. Accessed 19 March 2015</ref> On the other side of Frankfurt, around 3,000 attempted to break through the security fence of the ECB.<ref name="hr-170000"/> At least 350 people were arrested,<ref name="guardian-18032015">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/mar/18/anti-capitalist-protesters-clash-police-ecb-frankfurt-hq|title=At least 350 people arrested in protest at ECB HQ in Frankfurt|work=The Guardian|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> and 280 people were injured, among them 150 police officers and 130 protesters from Blockupy.<ref name="hr-170000"/><ref name="hr-19032015">{{cite news|url=http://www.hr-online.de/website/rubriken/nachrichten/index.jsp?rubrik=91009&key=standard_document_54830263&tl=rs|archive-url=https://archive.is/20150319091917/http://www.hr-online.de/website/rubriken/nachrichten/index.jsp?rubrik=91009&key=standard_document_54830263&tl=rs|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 March 2015|title=Ruhige Nacht nach Krawall-Tag|work=Hessischer Rundfunk|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=19 March 2015|language=German}}</ref> Violent scenes were reported. Organisers said police sparked this violence with provocative actions, and described it as "not what Blockupy planned",<ref name=dw_18032015/> while the [[Gewerkschaft der Polizei]] police union claimed that the violent protesters were organized and rejected claims of provocation.<ref name="hr-gdp">{{cite-news|title=Blockupy Frankfurt 2015 - Liveticker aus Frankfurt|url=http://www.scribblelive.com/Event/Blockupy_Frankfurt_2015_-_Liveticker_aus_Frankfurt/153292283|work=Hessischer Rundfunk|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=19 March 2015|language=German|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402124827/http://www.scribblelive.com/Event/Blockupy_Frankfurt_2015_-_Liveticker_aus_Frankfurt/153292283#|archive-date=2015-04-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The leader of the Hesse branch of the ''Linkspartei'', a member of the Blockupy alliance, said that the Blockupy movement had "failed" in its aim to offer peaceful protest and had brought the wider [[anti-capitalist]] movement into disrepute, a claim which was rejected by some of his party colleagues.<ref name="hr-18032015">{{cite news|url=http://www.hr-online.de/website/rubriken/nachrichten/indexhessen34938.jsp?rubrik=91009&key=standard_document_54822587|title=Reaktionen auf Krawalle: "Straftäter, die unterwegs waren"|work=Hessischer Rundfunk|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=19 March 2015|language=German}}</ref> The Blockupy representative from the [[Attac]] group described themselves as "appalled and saddened by some actions", but said that the majority of the protest was justified [[civil disobedience]].<ref name="faz-2015-03-19">{{cite news |url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/rhein-main/blockupy/blockupy-wehrt-sich-eskalation-war-nicht-ziel-13492647.html |title=Blockupy distanziert sich nicht von Gewalt |publisher=FAZ |date=2015-03-19 |accessdate=2015-03-19 |language=German}}</ref> Blockupy organizers from the Ums Ganze and Interventionist Left groups explicitly refused to distance themselves from the violence and expressed joy over the events.<ref name="faz-2015-03-19"/> Alongside the official members of the Blockupy alliance, the protests were also possibly attended by small groups at the opposite end of the [[political spectrum]], including members of the [[far-right]] and [[neo-Nazi]]s, although their number has not been determined.<ref name="hr-verfassungschutz">{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/blockupy-in-frankfurt-rechtsextremisten-mischten-bei-protest-mit-a-1024681.html||title=Rechtsextremisten mischten bei Blockupy-Protest mit|publisher=Spiegel|date=2015-03-20 |accessdate=2017-03-15 |language=German}}</ref> The [[Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution]] announced an investigation into whether the uninvited right-wing groups played a role in the violence that followed.<ref name="hr-verfassungschutz"/>
[[File:EZB Protest (16232443624).jpg|thumb|Damage done to Police station at the Frankfurt Zeil during European Central Bank protests 2015.|left]] Protesters attacked police officers with stones ahead of the demonstration.<ref name="dw_18032015" /> Video footage showed police dragging at least one person away.<ref name=dw_18032015>{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/violence-as-ecb-protest-begins-in-frankfurt/a-18322124|title=Violence has marred the start of anti-austerity rallies in Frankfurt, held to coincide with the European Central Bank (ECB) opening its new headquarters|work=Deutsche Welle|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> Police used [[tear gas]], [[water cannon]]s and [[pepper spray]] against people in the ECB area,<ref name="guardian-18032015"/> and in turn reported that "pepper spray or an acidic liquid" had been used against officers.<ref name="bbc-18032015"/> As well as the action against the ECB, some attendees also targeted private cars, shops, banks, firefighters and transport infrastructure. Eight [[bus stop|bus]] and [[tram stop]]s were vandalised, causing around €50,000 of damage,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vgf-ffm.de/de/aktuellpresse/news/einzelansicht/news/der_tag_danach_bahnen_und_busse_fahren_wieder/|title=Der Tag danach: Bahnen und Busse fahren wieder|author=VGF VerkehrsGesellschaft Frankfurt am Main|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=19 March 2015|language=German}}</ref> and trams and fire engines were attacked with stones.<ref name="hr-170000"/> According to police figures, 30 cars, including some police vehicles, were set on fire.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scribblelive.com/Event/Blockupy_Frankfurt_2015_-_Liveticker_aus_Frankfurt/153296985|work=Hessischer Rundfunk|title=Blockupy Frankfurt 2015 - Liveticker aus Frankfurt|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=19 March 2015|language=German|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402124830/http://www.scribblelive.com/Event/Blockupy_Frankfurt_2015_-_Liveticker_aus_Frankfurt/153296985#|archive-date=2015-04-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> A home for refugees was also supposedly attacked and staff threatened, which later turned out to be incorrect.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taz.de/!5015724/ |title=+++ Kein Stein flog gegen Flüchtlingsheim +++ |accessdate=2017-03-15 |date=2015-03-21 |publisher=Taz |language=German}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Occupy movement]], a similar movement from which the title is derived ** [[Occupy Berlin]], the German branch of this movement
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commonscat|Blockupy|Blockupy movement}} * [https://blockupy.org/en/ Official website] * [https://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2015/mar/18/blockupy-anti-ecb-protest-in-frankfurt-in-pictures Blockupy: anti-ECB protest in Frankfurt – in pictures]
[[Category:2012 protests]] [[Category:2013 protests]] [[Category:2014 protests]] [[Category:2015 protests]] [[Category:21st-century social movements]] [[Category:2012 riots]] [[Category:2013 riots]] [[Category:2014 riots]] [[Category:2015 riots]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Germany]] [[Category:Anti-austerity protests in the European Union]] [[Category:Civil disobedience]] [[Category:Community organizations]] [[Category:Protests]] [[Category:Social movements in Germany]]

There have been many conflicts during [[Critical Mass (cycling)|Critical Mass]] events since the founding of the worldwide bicycling [[advocacy]] event in 1992. The conflicts have resulted in injuries, property damage, and arrests, and both bicyclists and motorized vehicle drivers have been victims. Critics say that Critical Mass, held primarily in large [[Metropolitan area|metropolitan]] cities, is a deliberate attempt to obstruct automotive [[traffic]] and disrupt normal [[city]] functions, when individuals taking part refuse to obey [[Traffic code|traffic laws]],<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Winnipeg Sun|url=http://winnipegsun.com/News/Columnists/MacFarlane_Gord/2006/08/06/1722420.html|title=Critical Mass protesters too critical|author=Gord MacFarlane|date=August 7, 2006}}</ref> while participants variously consider it a celebration of cycling, of cyclists' rights, and a practical re-imagining of urban space.<ref>{{cite book|publisher=Wiley|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Kk_9vDOoU0QC&pg=PA137&lpg=PA137&dq=%22critical+mass%22+cycling+proponents&source=bl&ots=ZKCg-xJ4rg&sig=P-D5jGWsh5n5YoHJPporW88CWKw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAmoVChMIzMC0qOeWyAIVArwUCh3BBwQq#v=onepage&q=%22critical%20mass%22%20cycling%20proponents&f=false.|title=Critical Mass protesters too critical|author=Zack Furness|date=August 7, 2006}}</ref>
==Berkeley, California, US== On May 11, 2007, an incident occurred in [[Berkeley, California]], when an elderly motorist stopped at an [[Intersection (road)|intersection]] with dozens of [[bicycle]]s crossing.<ref name=cmc>{{cite news | last = Lee | first = Henry K. | title = Cyclist, motorists clash in Berkeley Critical Mass | publisher = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date = May 12, 2007 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/05/12/BAGIEPQ4IU69.DTL | accessdate = 2007-07-02}} </ref> [[Activism|Activists]] claim that the driver shouted, while bicyclists were in the intersection, "I'm sick of you people!" Police have not determined who had the [[Right-of-way (transportation)|right-of-way]].<ref name="sfgate.com">{{cite news | last = Jones | first = Carolyn | title = Accounts clash on Friday's row with bikes | publisher = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date = May 15, 2007 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/05/15/BAGQKPR2AC1.DTL }} </ref> The driver attempted to drive through the intersection.<ref name=cmc/> The motorist and his wife, two witnesses, and the police all claimed that the cyclists threw their bicycles under the vehicle. This was disputed by other witnesses.<ref name="cmc"/><ref name="sfgate.com"/><ref>{{cite news | last = Cisneros | first = Noel | title = Elderly Couple Tangles With Cyclists | publisher = KGO-TV, San Francisco, Oakland, San Jose | date = May 12, 2007 | url = http://google.com/search?q=cache:vaqAI34OVDEJ:abclocal.go.com/kgo/story%3Fsection%3Dlocal%26id%3D5299419+%22Gabe+schnake-mahl%22&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=4&gl=us }} </ref> Critical Mass participants then rocked the vehicle, pounded the hood, and broke the windshield while verbally abusing the elderly couple.<ref>{{cite news | last = Lee | first = Henry K. | title = Elderly couple caught up in altercation with Critical Mass bicyclists | publisher = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date = May 13, 2007 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/05/13/BAGNLPQ6MJ1.DTL | accessdate = 2007-07-02}} </ref> Approximately $3,000 worth of damage was done to the bicycles. Berkeley police did not make any arrests in the incident.
==Buffalo, New York, US== On May 30, 2003, in [[Buffalo, New York]], during an incident known locally as "Critical Massacre," police stopped two cyclists for "failure to yield to an [[emergency vehicle]]." Several people were allegedly attacked by police. Nine cyclists were arrested and three were later convicted, including a journalist.<ref>http://www.mediastudy.com/articles/av5-27-04.html</ref>
==Chicago, Illinois, US== [[Image:Chicago june 27 2008 critical mass arrest in Bridgeport.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A cyclist at the June 27, 2008 [[Chicago]] [[Critical Mass (cycling)|Critical Mass]] is arrested for public drinking.]] [[Chicago Police Department]] officers are often seen riding with Critical Mass participants, and squad cars block intersections to provide safe passage to Critical Mass cyclists. However, on August 31, 2007, seven riders were arrested on charges of obstructing traffic and disobeying police, and were held overnight. According to some of those arrested, they were released late at night or early in the morning. On multiple occasions, Critical Mass participants attempted to ride on [[Lake Shore Drive]], a road off limits to cyclists. Police prevented participants riding on Lake Shore Drive, by blocking entrance ramps with squad cars when Critical Mass riders approach the road.<ref>{{cite web |title= Tips For Newcomers |url=http://chicagocriticalmass.org/about/newbies |accessdate=5 August 2009}}</ref>
==Honolulu, Hawaii, US== At dusk on March 28, 2008, in [[Honolulu, Hawaii]], police collided with a young woman on a bicycle while trying to stop another bicyclist for traffic infractions. The young woman fell and hit her head on the ground, sustaining injuries requiring hospitalization. While no arrests were made, the police did issue [[Traffic ticket|citations]] and confiscate bicycles.<ref>David, Mari-Ela. [http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/Global/story.asp?S=8230852 Police Step Up Patrols at Critical Mass.] ''Hawaii News Now.'' 26 April 2008.</ref>
==Houston, Texas, US== Due to the gradual increase of cyclists participating in Critical Mass, as well as complaints from motorists and concerns for safety, [[Houston Police Department]] officers helped direct the October 2013 Critical Mass ride in [[Houston, Texas]] by controlling intersections on the bike route.<ref>{{cite web |title= 2000 Cyclists Participate in Critical Mass |url=http://www.khou.com/news/local/2000-cyclists-participate-in-Critical-Mass-229348351.html |accessdate = 5 January 2014}}</ref> In January 2014, after two months of providing free security and safe passage through heavy intersections, the [[Houston Police Department]] began considering options to charge the group for providing security for the event, citing similarities to providing security for funeral processions through the [[city]] limits.<ref>{{cite web |title= Critical Mass is free, but Houston police may begin charging riders for escort |url=http://www.chron.com/default/article/Critical-Mass-is-free-but-Houston-police-may-5108973.php|accessdate = 5 January 2014}}</ref> Some Critical Mass riders have spoken out in protest of paying a fee to utilize extra security and escorting through busy intersections, while many others support paying fees for extra security to keep the ride safe,<ref>{{cite web |title= Critical Mass says paying for Houston police escorts not an option |url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Critical-Mass-says-paying-for-Houston-police-5111821.php#src=fb |accessdate = 5 January 2014}}</ref> which has led to increased discussions between the [[city]] and group for additional alternatives to the building conflicts.<ref>{{cite web |title= Houston Police Department may stop providing security for monthly cycling event Critical Mass |url=http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=news/local&id=9381009|accessdate = 5 January 2014}}</ref>
==London, United Kingdom== [[Image:Metropolitan Police officers at Critical Mass London, April 2006.jpg|right|thumb|[[Metropolitan Police]] officers with their cycles awaiting the start of Critical Mass London, April 2006.]] In [[London]] on September 2005, a few weeks after the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|7 July 2005 bombings]], Metropolitan Police required the organisers to provide a route six days before the event and placed strict restrictions on riders under threat of arrest. The threat was retracted when politicians and cyclist groups objected. In October 2005, the ride had close to 1,200 participants, significantly more than usual. A long stop in [[Parliament Square]], part of the government's exclusion area in the [[Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005]], led to a slow and cumbersome ride.
One participant sought a declaration from the [[High Court of England and Wales]] that police need not be notified about the rides, in a "friendly action" in which neither side sought [[damages]]. The High Court<ref name=kayvc>{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Admin/2006/1536.html|title=Kay v. the Commissioner of the Police of the Metropolis, EWHC 1536 (Admin)|date=June 27, 2006|publisher=Royal Courts of Justice}}</ref> agreed, exempting Critical Mass from notification under Section 11 of the [[Public Order Act 1986]]. The ruling was reversed on appeal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2007/477.html|title=Kay v. the Commissioner of the Police of the Metropolis (appeal)|date=May 21, 2007|publisher=Royal Courts of Justice}}</ref> In 2008, [[Friends of the Earth]], who supported the legal action, said the case would be appealed to England's highest legal authority, the [[House of Lords]], on the grounds that, after 11 years, Critical Mass is "commonly or customarily held." In October 2008, the House of Lords ruled in favour of the Critical Mass participant.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/nov/26/critical-mass-london-police |title = Critical Mass police ban blocked by law lords |publisher = guardian.co.uk |date = November 26, 2008 |accessdate = 2009-02-21 | location=London }}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url = https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200708/ldjudgmt/jd081126/metro-1.htm |title = Judgments - Kay (FC)(Appellant) v Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis (Respondent) |publisher = House of Lords |date = November 26, 2008 |accessdate = 2009-02-21 }}</ref>
During the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], cyclists were arrested on opening day after police claim they ignored regulations in place during the Olympics. [[Jenny Jones (Green politician)|Jenny Jones]] of the [[Green Party of England and Wales|Green Party]] and the [[London Assembly|Greater London Assembly]] has questioned the police actions, calling them "out of all proportion to common sense"<ref>http://greenparty.org.uk/news/2012/07/31/green-party-call-on-the-mayor-to-keep-civil-liberties-at-the-forefront-during-the-olympics/</ref> and "tragically unnecessary."<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/jenny-jones-am/london-olympics-what-is-the-cost_b_1755785.html</ref> A Critical Mass website asked riders to be "peacefully assertive" during the monthly ride, while police claim they asked riders to keep to the south of the [[River Thames]]. When the riders got close to the [[Olympic Park, London|Olympic Park]], police began to cordon off the area and arrest riders.<ref> {{cite web |url = https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/jul/28/critical-mass-cyclists-arrested?CMP=twt_gu |title = Critical Mass cyclists arrested near Olympic Stadium |publisher = The Guardian |date = 27 July 2012 |accessdate = 28 July 2012 }}</ref> In total, 182 people were arrested, of whom 4 were charged, and 178 were [[bail]]ed pending further inquiries.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://content.met.police.uk/News/182-people-arrested-in-protest/1400010375724/1257246745756 |title = 182 people arrested in protest |publisher = Metropolitan Police Service |date = 27 July 2012 |accessdate = 2 August 2012 }}</ref> The action led to 5 of the 182 people arrested being convicted in court.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.gamesmonitor.org.uk/node/2002|title= Another Olympics Cycling Legacy - Critical Mass Convictions}}</ref>
==Minneapolis, Minnesota, US== On the August 31, 2007, ride in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]], a confrontation occurred between cyclists and the police. The police presence included [[Undercover operation|undercover]] officers, three marked [[Police car|squad cars]], a state [[patrol]] helicopter, and unmarked vehicles. The ride had been linked with weekend protests of the following year's [[2008 Republican National Convention|Republican National Convention]]. After the arrest of a cyclist for "riding in a snake-like manner," cyclists began chanting "Let him go!" and "What's the charge?" The police called for backup, and dozens of police officers responded, using [[Mace (spray)|mace]] and [[taser]]s. Minneapolis police arrested 19 participants, including three [[Minor (law)|minors]]. The adults were arrested on suspicion of rioting, a [[gross misdemeanor]].<ref>[http://www.startribune.com/467/story/1396202.html September 1: 19 bicyclists arrested after rally turns into melee<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://cmsupport.wordpress.com Minneapolis Critical Mass Arrestee Support<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Minsk, Belarus== On May 27, 2011, in [[Minsk]], Belarus, police forces aided by special units transported 13 cyclists to the police station for violation of traffic rules and for not following orders to disband. Detained participants were [[fingerprint]]ed and fined, then released.<ref>http://belarus.indymedia.org/24151</ref>
On April 30, 2016 two cyclists were arrested<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.tut.by/society/494751.html|title=У двух задержанных 29 апреля в Минске велосипедистов прошли обыски|language=ru-RU|access-date=2016-09-27}}</ref> during a Critical Mass action. As of September 2016, one was released and the other is facing trial.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.tut.by/society/513642.html|title=Велосипедиста, обвиненного в насилии в отношении гаишника, будут судить еще и за порнографию|language=ru-RU|access-date=2016-09-27}}</ref>
==New York City, New York, US== Police in [[New York City]] have claimed that Critical Mass bicyclists blocking intersections to allow bikes to pass may delay emergency vehicles in the [[gridlock]].<ref name=usatoday>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2004-11-15-bikes-new-york_x.htm|date=November 15, 2004|publisher=USA Today|title=Big pack of bikes piques police|author=Martha T. Moore}}</ref>
===2004 Republican National Convention=== During the US [[2004 Republican National Convention]], police arrested 250 riders after the ride caused "massive disruptions" in the city.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2004/ALLPOLITICS/08/28/rnc.bike.protest/|publisher=CNN|title=264 arrested in NYC bicycle protest|author=Jonathan Wald|date=August 29, 2004|accessdate=2008-02-23}}</ref> Many court cases resulted regarding the legality of the ride, whether police have the right to arrest cyclists and seize bicycles, and whether the event needs a [[Protest permit|permit]]. In December 2004, a federal judge dismissed New York City's [[injunction]] against Critical Mass as a "political event."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nysd.uscourts.gov/courtweb/pdf/D02NYSC/04-08621.PDF|format=PDF|title=Bray v. City of New York, 04 Civ 8255 (WHP) (USDC, SD NY, 2004}}</ref> On March 23, 2005, the city filed a lawsuit seeking to prevent [[Time's Up!]], a [[direct action]] [[environmental group]], from promoting or advertising Critical Mass rides. The lawsuit also stated that Time's Up! and the public could not ride or gather at a Critical Mass bike ride, claiming a permit was required.
===2008 bicycle rally=== During a bicycle rally on July 25, 2008, [[NYPD]] patrolman Patrick Pogan pushed rider Christopher Long off his bicycle.<ref name="nytimes080729a">{{cite news | first = James | last = Barron | title = Officer Investigated in Toppling of Cyclist | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/29/nyregion/29critical.html | work = The New York Times | location = New York City, New York | page = B1 | date = 2008-07-29 | accessdate = 2009-03-07}}</ref> In a criminal complaint, Pogan wrote that he had ordered Long to stop because he was weaving in and out of traffic, forcing vehicles to swerve or stop, and generally disrupting the normal flow of traffic. In addition, Pogan wrote that he suffered [[lacerations]] on his arms because Long steered his bike into him and knocked him down, and when he tried to place Long under arrest, Long began flailing, kicking and screaming, "You are pawns in the game!"<ref name="nytimes080729a" /> Long spent the next day in [[Detention (imprisonment)|police custody]] on charges of attempted assault, resisting arrest and [[disorderly conduct]].<ref name="nytimes090730">{{cite news | first = Jim | last = Dwyer | title = When Official Truth Collides With Cheap Digital Technology | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/30/nyregion/30about.html | work = The New York Times | location = New York City, New York | page = B1 | date = 2008-07-30 | accessdate = 2009-03-07}}</ref>
Within days, members of the rally's sponsoring organization [[Time's Up!]] posted a video of the incident on [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Critical Mass Bicyclist Assaulted by NYPD|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUkiyBVytRQ|website=YouTube|publisher=downsouthvids|accessdate=June 28, 2016|date=July 25, 2008}}</ref><ref name="nytimes080729b">{{cite news | first = Colin | last = Moynihan | title = The Officer, the Bicyclist and the Video | url =http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/07/29/the-officer-the-bicyclist-and-the-video/ | work = The New York Times | location = New York City, New York | date = 2008-07-29 | accessdate = 2009-03-07}}</ref> The video went [[Viral phenomenon|viral]] and received over 400,000 [[Hit (Internet)|hits]] within five days. Critical Mass activists claimed it supported their claims that the police department has demonstrated a pattern of arresting participants in the rally on false charges.<ref name="nytimes080729b" /> Witnesses also disputed Pogan's account, saying that Long was the one to receive injuries, traffic was stopped for the rally, and that Pogan had simply scanned the group of cyclists to find one he could take down.<ref name="nytimes080729a" />
The [[Patrolmen's Benevolent Association|union]] that represents NYPD officers said Pogan was just doing his job to protect the public from a reckless bike rider,<ref>{{cite news | first = Murray | last = Weiss | title = Cop union's spin on bike tackler | url =http://www.nypost.com/seven/07302008/news/regionalnews/cop_unions_spin_on_bike_tackler_122209.htm | work = The New York Post | location = New York City, New York | date = 2008-07-30 | accessdate = 2009-03-07}}</ref> and Pogan's father — himself a retired NYPD [[detective]] — defended him, saying "You gotta do what you gotta do to make an arrest."<ref>{{cite news | first = Tamer | last = El-Ghobashy | title = Shock over cop's bike slam video | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2008/07/28/2008-07-28_rookie_cop_in_hot_water_after_video_show.html | work = The New York Daily News | location = New York City, New York | page = 3 | date = 2008-07-29 | accessdate = 2009-03-07}}</ref> The [[New York County District Attorney|prosecutor]]'s office dismissed the charges against Long. NYPD placed Pogan, who had spent only three weeks as a police officer, on a desk assignment while the city investigated the incident.<ref name="tribune090307">{{cite news|first=Maull |last=Samuel |title=Charges dismissed against cyclist in YouTube shove |url=http://wcbstv.com/local/NYC.YouTube.Cyclist.2.810857.html |agency=The Associated Press |date=2009-09-05 |accessdate=2009-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424044456/http://wcbstv.com/local/NYC.YouTube.Cyclist.2.810857.html |archivedate=April 24, 2010 }}</ref>
On December 16, 2008, Pogan appeared in court and pleaded not guilty to [[felony]] charges of falsifying business records and filing a false instrument, and [[misdemeanor]] charges of third-degree [[assault]], second-degree [[harassment]] and making a punishable false written statement.<ref name="ap081216">{{cite news |title=NYC cop seen in YouTube shove pleads not guilty |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2008/12/15/national/a190557S13.DTL |agency=The Associated Press |date=2008-12-16 |accessdate=2009-03-07 |work=The San Francisco Chronicle |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505202507/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fn%2Fa%2F2008%2F12%2F15%2Fnational%2Fa190557S13.DTL |archivedate=May 5, 2009 |df= }}</ref> After the [[indictment]], the police department suspended Pogan<ref name="ap081216" /> and, two months later, Pogan resigned as the department prepared to fire him.<ref>{{cite news|title=Clarification: YouTube cyclist story |url=http://a.abcnews.com/US/wireStory?id=6960284 |agency=The Associated Press |date=2009-02-25 |accessdate=2009-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707073738/http://a.abcnews.com/US/wireStory?id=6960284 |archivedate=July 7, 2011 }}</ref> His attorney said that his defense would center on the department's training procedures and claims that events occurring off-camera needed to be taken into account.<ref>{{cite news | first = Chris | last = Kokenes | title = Officer resigns after video shows him knocking down cyclist | url =http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/02/20/youtube.cyclist/ | agency = CNN | location = Atlanta, Georgia | date = 2009-02-20 | accessdate = 2009-03-07}}</ref>
On July 8, 2009, it was reported that Long, then a [[Hoboken, NJ]], resident, was suing the New York Police Department for $1.5 million, alleging that Pogan falsified his arrest report in order to legitimize his assault on Long.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/hobokennow/index.ssf/2009/07/bodychecked_new_york_city_cycl.html|title=Bodychecked cyclist suing NYPD for $1.5 million|date=July 8, 2009|publisher=Hoboken Now|accessdate=2009-07-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2009/07/07/2009-07-07_cyclist_seeks_15m_from_city_for_body_slam.html|title=Cyclist sues NYPD for $1.5M after YouTube vid captures cop body slam|date=July 7, 2009|publisher=''Daily News''|accessdate=2009-07-16 | location=New York | first=Simone | last=Weichselbaum}}</ref>
During his trial in April 2010, Pogan acknowledged that the video looked "very extreme."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/24/nyregion/24pogan.html|title=Former Officer Testifies in Bicyclist-Shoving Case|last=Eligon|first=John|date=April 23, 2010|work=The New York Times|accessdate=May 4, 2010}}</ref> He testified that he had anticipated a collision with Long, since the rider lowered his right shoulder as the officer approached. Jurors found Pogan not guilty of harassment and assault and acquitted him of four of the seven counts of which he had been charged. He was found guilty of filing a criminal complaint that contained false statements concerning the cyclist.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/04/29/2010-04-29_excop_caught_on_video_knocking_bicyclist_down_not_guilty_of_assault_guilty_of_fa.html|title=Ex-cop caught on video knocking bicyclist down not guilty of assault, guilty of falsifying complaint |last=Grace|first=Melissa|date=April 29, 2010|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=May 3, 2010}}</ref> Pogan received no jail time but, because he is a convicted [[Felony|felon]], he is not eligible to become a New York City police officer in the future.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9GVH7JG0.htm | title=Ex-officer gets no jail time in NYC bicycle clash | work=Business Week | date=July 15, 2010 | accessdate=September 3, 2011 | author=Peltz, Jennifer}}</ref> Long said in an interview that he was pleased with the verdict, in part because it would prevent Pogan from becoming a New York City police officer again.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/30/nyregion/30pogan.html|title=Ex-Officer Convicted of Lying About Confrontation With Cyclist|last=Eligon|first=John|date=April 29, 2010|work=The New York Times|accessdate=May 4, 2010}}</ref>
==Porto Alegre, Brazil== On February 25, 2011, an automobile driver deliberately collided with around 20 cyclists that were participating in a Critical Mass event in Rua José do Patrocinio in [[Porto Alegre]], southern [[Brazil]]. Out of approximately 150 people that were taking part in the event, dozens of bicycles were damaged, 15 people were injured and eight were transported to the [[Emergency department|emergency room]]. While the driver left the scene of the incident, demonstrators remained on the street, demanding that the driver be found and arrested.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://zerohora.clicrbs.com.br/zerohora/jsp/default.jsp?uf=1&local=1&section=Geral&newsID=a3221536.xml&dsadsad | title = Grupo de ciclistas é atropelado na Cidade Baixa, em Porto Alegre | author = | date = 2011-02-25 | publisher = Zero Hora | language = Portuguese | accessdate = 2011-02-25 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.correiodopovo.com.br/Noticias/?Noticia=261933 | title = Ciclistas são atropelados por carro no bairro Cidade Baixa | author = Gisiane Andrade dos Santos | date = 2011-02-25 | publisher = Correio do Povo | language = Portuguese | accessdate = 2011-02-25 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://noticias.terra.com.br/brasil/transito/noticias/0,,OI4963539-EI998,00-Motorista+atropela+grupo+de+ciclistas+fere+e+foge+no+RS.html | title = Motorista atropela grupo de ciclistas, fere 10 e foge no RS | author = Maurício Tonetto | date = 2011-02-25 | publisher = Terra | language = Portuguese | accessdate = 2011-02-25 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Brazilian-Car-Hits-Cyclists-Injuring-Dozens-Of-People-at-Critical-Mass-Event-In-Porto-Alegre/Article/201102415942687?lpos=World_News_Second_Home_Page_Article_Teaser_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15942687_Brazilian_Car_Hits_Cyclists_Injuring_Dozens_Of_People_at_Critical_Mass_Event_In_Porto_Alegre_ | title = Driver Ploughs Car Into Brazilian Cyclists | author = David Connoly | date = 2011-02-28 | publisher = Sky News | accessdate = 2011-02-28 }}</ref> The driver was later identified as 47-year-old Ricardo José Neis. After Neis gave his statement to the police, his attorney, Luis Fernando Coimbra Albino, stated that the Neis was acting in self-defense after several cyclists threatened him and his son and assaulted his car.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://zerohora.clicrbs.com.br/zerohora/jsp/default.jsp?uf=1&local=1&section=Geral&newsID=a3224097.xml | title = Motorista que atropelou ciclistas na Capital se apresenta à Polícia Civil | author = | date = 2011-02-28 | publisher = Zero Hora | language = Portuguese | accessdate = 2011-02-28 }}</ref> According to witnesses present at the event, Neis was acting violently behind the bicycles and hit the rear wheels of two different cyclists, and any contact from the cyclists on his car was meant as a sign asking him to slow the vehicle down. Witnesses also reported that Neis had two different [[Transversal (geometry)|transversal]] roads he could have taken to avoid waiting for the cyclists to proceed.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://noticias.terra.com.br/brasil/transito/noticias/0,,OI4966638-EI998,00-RS+ciclistas+negam+versao+da+defesa+ele+e+um+psicopata.html | title = RS: ciclistas negam versão da defesa: 'ele é um psicopata' | author = | date = 2011-02-28 | publisher = Terra News | language = Portuguese | accessdate = 2011-03-04 }}</ref> On March 1, 2011, Neis attempted to transfer from a hospital to a [[Psychiatric hospital|psychiatric clinic]], but this request was rejected by court officials. He was held in the hospital under police custody,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://zerohora.clicrbs.com.br/zerohora/jsp/default.jsp?uf=1&local=1&section=Geral&newsID=a3229140.xml | title = Justiça nega pedido de transferência de atropelador para o Instituto Psiquiátrico Forense | author = | date = 2011-03-04 | publisher = Zero Hora | language = Portuguese | accessdate = 2011-03-04 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://ultimosegundo.ig.com.br/brasil/rs/motorista%2Bque%2Batropelou%2Bciclistas%2Bconsegue%2Bse%2Binternar%2Bem%2Bclinica/n1238126184655.html&prev=_t&rurl=translate.google.co.uk&usg=ALkJrhjXE_UK1uCEvqhMthqAZLwsARYxNw | title = Motorista que atropelou ciclistas consegue se internar em clínica | author = | date = 2011-03-01 | publisher = Ultimo Segundo - IG | language = Portuguese | accessdate = 2011-03-04 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://road.cc/content/news/31562-brazilian-critical-mass-driver-says-he-had-no-alternative%E2%80%A6-they-broke-mirror | title = Brazilian Critical Mass driver Ricardo Neis charged with attempted murder + Neis video | author = | date = 2011-03-02 | publisher = road.cc | accessdate = 2011-03-04 }}</ref> but was later released and [[Indictment|indicted]] under 17 counts of attempted murder.<ref>http://www.theurbancountry.com/2011/04/brazil-critical-mass-updateinterview.html</ref> One of the most severely injured cyclists, 23-year-old Ricardo Mattes Ambus, was readmitted to the hospital on March 3, 2011, due to an [[Intracranial hemorrhage|intracranial haematoma]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://noticias.terra.com.br/brasil/transito/noticias/0,,OI4972883-EI998,00-RS+ciclista+atropelado+tem+confusao+mental+e+volta+ao+hospital.html | title = RS: ciclista atropelado tem confusão mental e volta ao hospital | author = | date = 2011-03-03 | publisher = Terra News | accessdate = 2011-03-04 }}</ref>
During the following week, between February 28 and March 6, 2011, many protests in support of Critical Mass Porto Alegre were organized in several major cities in [[South America]] and around the world.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Glock|first1=Clarinha|title=BRAZIL: Porto Alegre Cyclists Step Up Demands for Bike Lanes|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2011/04/brazil-porto-alegre-cyclists-step-up-demands-for-bike-lanes/|accessdate=26 September 2014|agency=Inter Press Service|date=April 5, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=John|first1=Timothy|title=Attack on cyclists inspires Bournemouth Critical Mass ride|url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/8941475.Attack_on_cyclists_inspires_Bournemouth_Critical_Mass_ride/|accessdate=26 September 2014|agency=Daily Echo|date=30 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Noah|first1=Marcelo|title=Protesto contra atropelamento de ciclistas reúne 2 mil em Porto Alegre|url=http://www.brasildefato.com.br/node/5818|accessdate=September 26, 2014|agency=Brasil de Fato|date=March 11, 2011|language=Portuguese}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ciclistas fazem ato em solidariedade às vítimas de Porto Alegre|url=http://www.vermelho.org.br/noticia/148700-8|accessdate=26 September 2014|agency=Portal Vermelho|date=March 2, 2011|language=Portuguese}}</ref> In response, local cyclists organized the [[World Bike Forum]] in [[Porto Alegre]] to raise awareness of violence in traffic against cyclists.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scruggs|first1=Greg|title=A Critical Mass Tragedy Sparks a Bicycle Boom in Brazil|url=http://nextcity.org/daily/entry/critical-mass-tragedy-sparks-a-bicycle-boom-in-brazil-porto-alegre|website=Next City|accessdate=25 September 2014}}</ref> The first Forum took place during the anniversary of the incident.
On November 24, 2016, Ricardo Neis was sentenced to 12 years and 9 months in jail for attempted murder and aggravated assault.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ricardo Neis é condenado a mais de 12 anos de prisão|url=http://www.correiodopovo.com.br/Noticias/Policia/2016/11/603818/Ricardo-Neis-e-condenado-a-mais-de-12-anos-de-prisao|accessdate=25 November 2016|agency=Correio do Povo|date=November 24, 2016|language=Portuguese}}</ref>
==San Francisco, California, US==
===July 1997===
On the night of July 25, 1997, in [[San Francisco]], the ride attracted 5,000 participants, which resulted in congested traffic, confrontations with motorists, and arrests. Interest and tension had been growing for several weeks due to increased [[rhetoric]] from then-Mayor [[Willie Brown (politician)|Willie Brown]] regarding cracking down on the event. The local newspapers published a city-approved route after the mayor withdrew his threat to have bicyclists arrested for not obtaining a [[parade]] permit. Because of the large turnout, it was difficult if not impossible for cyclists to follow the sanctioned route. Riders instead found themselves engaged in verbal and physical altercations with motorists and police, as well as among themselves. Two officers reported injuries in confrontations with bike riders. Local media reported that "about 250" bicyclists were arrested, most for disrupting traffic, and a few for being drunk in public, [[Battery (crime)|battery]], and outstanding [[Warrant (law)|warrants]].<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1997/07/26/MN20246.DTL&hw=critical+mass&sn=001&sc=1000 |title = S.F. Bike Chaos – 250 Arrests: 5,000 bikers snarl commute |publisher = San Francisco Chronicle |author = Glen Martin |accessdate = 2009-01-22 | date=July 26, 1997 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://guest.xinet.com/bike/sfcm/july97/main.htm |title=Critical Mass, San Francisco July 25, 1997 |publisher=Mark Motyka |author=Mark Motyka |accessdate=2009-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040302122822/http://guest.xinet.com/bike/sfcm/july97/main.htm |archivedate=March 2, 2004 }}</ref>
===March 2007=== On the March 2007 ride in San Francisco, a rider was arrested on felony (later reduced to misdemeanor) charges in San Francisco's [[Tenderloin, San Francisco, California|Tenderloin neighborhood]] for denting a [[limousine]] using a [[bicycle lock]]. The driver told police he got out of his car to talk to two cyclists who allegedly blocked his path. After exchanging words with one of the cyclists, the driver said he grabbed one of the bicycles and tried to pull it out of the way. He then got back into his limo to go around the riders, but before he could move, he said, another cyclist ran into the side of his car, then punched the hood with a U-shaped lock. The cyclist told police he only hit the limousine after the driver gunned his engine. During the incident, one of the limousine's tires was slashed and the driver's keys were stolen.<ref>{{cite news |title=Another run-in with Critical Mass: Shattered window of family car wasn't only encounter – limo had harrowing clash, too |author=Phillip Matier, Andrew Ross |date=April 8, 2007 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/04/08/BAG0SP504J1.DTL | work=The San Francisco Chronicle }}</ref>
Towards the end of the ride, near the [[Japantown, San Francisco, California|Japan Center]] and [[Western Addition]] neighborhoods, a mother from [[Redwood City, California]], traveling with her two young daughters in the vehicle, tried to drive through the mass of riders. A witness claimed to have observed the driver strike a cyclist and flee before cyclists chased and surrounded her vehicle.<ref>{{cite news |last = Gonzalez |first = Richard |title = Bicyclists, Motorist Clash in San Francisco |publisher = [[National Public Radio]] |date = April 2007 |url = https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=9496562 |accessdate = 2007-07-02}} </ref><ref>{{cite news |last = Lee |first = Henry, K. |title = Elderly couple caught up in altercation with Critical Mass bicyclists |publisher = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date = May 13, 2007 |url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/05/13/BAGNLPQ6MJ1.DTL&type=printable |accessdate = 2007-07-02}} </ref> The driver denied striking a cyclist and alleged that hundreds of cyclists surrounded her minivan while she and her 11- and 13-year-old daughters were inside, banged on her car, scratched the paint, and threw a bicycle through the rear window of the vehicle, causing $5,300 in damages.<ref>{{cite news |last = Rubenstein |first = Steve |author2=Lee, Henry K |author3=Zamora, Jim |title = Critical Mass pedals politely through S.F. |publisher = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date = April 28, 2007 |url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/04/28/MNGF2PHDCK1.DTL |accessdate = 2007-07-02}} </ref><ref>http://www.fogcityjournal.com/news_in_brief/bcn_critical_mass_070405.shtml</ref>
In April 2007, San Francisco Mayor [[Gavin Newsom]] requested that Critical Mass riders police themselves. "It does the bicycle-advocacy community no good to have people that are aggressive and dispirit the entire movement," Newsom said. "I would encourage the bicycle [[coalition]] to say, 'Look, we don't put up with this, enough is enough.' "<ref>{{cite news |publisher=San Francisco Chronicle |title=Mayor vows 'a good look' at Critical Mass: Redwood City family's van damaged after being caught up in ride |author=Cecilia Vega |date=April 4, 2007 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/04/04/BAGLRP2LEI8.DTL&type=printable }}</ref>
===November 2009===
In November 2009, Stanley Roberts of [[KRON]] 4 News recorded several Critical Mass confrontations between bicyclists and vehicles at [[Van Ness Avenue (San Francisco)|Van Ness]] and O'Farrell Streets. An old Critical Mass website advised riders not to be confrontational and block traffic, but in footage filmed by Roberts, bicyclists engaged in confrontational arguments with motorists and blocked roads to vehicular traffic.<ref name="KRON4">{{cite web |url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IyJWXWr7YCg&feature=related |title = Critical Mass SF - People Behaving Badly |publisher = KRON 4 News |author = Stanley Roberts |date = November 3, 2009 }}</ref>
===August 2015===
In August 2015, [[KQED]] posted an article on a Critical Mass confrontation between a bicyclist and a female [[Zipcar]] driver in the San Francisco Marina District. 39 year old Ian Hespelt was arrested a few days later by the San Francisco Police Department's bicycle patrol at [[AT&T Park]] during the [[Billy Joel]] concert. Hespelt was charged with four felonies including assault, vandalism, maliciously throwing a substance at a vehicle and false imprisonment. Hespelt was also wanted in Washington state on a felony drug charge warrant.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://ww2.kqed.org/news/2015/08/31/video-confrontation-between-critical-mass-bicyclist-and-driver-in-s-f |title = Video: Confrontation Between Critical Mass Bicyclist and Driver in S.F. |publisher = [[KQED]] |author = Patricia Yollin |date = August 31, 2015 }}</ref>
==Seattle, Washington, US==
===June 2006=== Two riders were arrested during the June 2006 ride in [[Seattle, Washington]], after a fight with two undercover detectives whom the cyclists confused for [[gang]] members.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=40118|publisher=The Stranger|title=Mass Attack: Undercover County Cops Disrupt Monthly Bike Ride, Arrest Two|author1=Josh Feit|author2= Sarah Mirk|authorlink2 = Sarah Mirk|accessdate=2008-02-23}}</ref> Witnesses disputed the claim made by the sheriff's office that the detectives identified themselves.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=41651|work=the Stranger|title=Critical Mass Incident Update|date=July 11, 2006|accessdate=2008-02-23}}</ref> The [[King County Sheriff's Office]] decided not to press felony charges in the case, saying there were too many issues over the circumstances surrounding the [[allegation]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/278988_bicyclist27.html|title=Bicyclist won't be charged with felony for assaulting deputies|date=July 27, 2006|accessdate=2009-02-26|work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer|first1=Hector|last1=Castro}}</ref>
===July 2008=== On July 25, 2008, Critical Mass prevented a motorist from driving from a curbside [[parking space]] into cyclists<ref>{{cite news | title = Critical Mass riders injure driver in Capitol Hill altercation | publisher = The Seattle Times Company | date = July 26, 2008 | url = http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2008074874_webcriticalmass26m.html }}</ref> in [[Seattle]]'s Critical Mass on East Aloha. The motorist made statements to [[Seattle Police Department|Seattle police]] that he drove away, hitting bicycles and riders (one of them an attorney),<ref name="seattlepi_372364">{{cite news | last = Castro | first = Hector | title = Motorist clashes with bicycle protesters | publisher = King 5 News (KONG) | date = July 26, 2008 | url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/372364_criticalmass27.html?source=mypi }} </ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Braun | first = Tom | title = Photo of Tom Braun's crushed bicycle | publisher = Seattle Times | date = July 27, 2008 | url = http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/ABPub/zoom/html/2008075744.html }} </ref> and told the press that he "freaked out and overreacted" when bicyclists threatened to tip his vehicle.<ref name="seattletimes_2008078135">{{cite news | last = Green | first = Sarah Jean | title = Driver says he was provoked, but overreacted in Critical Mass incident | publisher = Seattle Times | date = July 28, 2008 | url = http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2008078135_webmotorist28m.html }} </ref> According to some witnesses, the motorist drove into at least two cyclists and tried to flee.<ref name="king5_072508">{{cite news | last = Hahn | first = Elisa | title = Bicycle Demonstration Turns Violent | publisher = King 5 News (KONG) | date = April 5, 2007 | url = http://www.king5.com/localnews/stories/NW_072508WAB_car_vs_cyclists_KC.262be9a.html }} </ref>
A group of riders caught the vehicle, broke its rear windshield, slashed the tires, and assaulted the motorist when he got out. Damage to the car was estimated at $1,500.<ref name="seattlepi_372364"/><ref name="king5_072508"/> The motorist was struck in the back of his head by a bike lock<ref name="seattletimes_2008078135"/> and later hospitalized.<ref>{{cite news | last = Castro | first = Hector | title = Monthly bicycle protest marred by violence | publisher = Seattle Post Intelligencer | date = July 27, 2008 | url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/372364_criticalmass27.html }} </ref> Two cyclists were arrested for [[vandalism]] to the car. Seattle police did not charge the motorist.<ref>{{cite news | last = Spangenthal-Lee | first = Jonah | title = Critical Error | publisher = The Stranger | date = July 29, 2008 | url = http://thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=632154&hp }} </ref>
==Vilnius, Lithuania== On July 27, 2007, in [[Vilnius, Lithuania]], police took five participants into custody, including two minors, for not following orders to disband.
==Walnut Creek, California, US== In [[Walnut Creek, California]], on June 20, 2008, a car bumped into the rear wheel of a Critical Mass rider. An argument ensued among the driver and passenger of the car and the cyclist involved, after which the passenger and driver of the car assaulted the cyclist. The police arrived and arrested the passenger and driver of the automobile involved in the assault.<ref>http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/06/20/18509674.php</ref>
==Warsaw, Poland== On June 21, 2002, in [[Warsaw, Poland]], the Critical Mass event was stopped by a cordon of fully armed [[riot police]] on [[Constitution Square (Warsaw)|Plac Konstytucji (Constitution Square)]], who demanded their dispersal and detained some of the participants. Other Critical Mass participants responded with a [[Sit-in|sit-in protest]], blocking an important traffic [[Junction (traffic)|junction]], and then tried to evade the [[blockade]] by taking different routes to [[Castle Square, Warsaw|Plac Zamkowy (Castle Square)]], the Critical Mass rally point.<ref>http://www.raster.art.pl/galeria/artysci/rowelucja/rowelucja.htm</ref><ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20080603011249/http://www.masa.waw.pl/2002/0621.html</ref><ref>http://wiadomosci.gazeta.pl/kraj/1,34309,890904.html {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120710195928/http://wiadomosci.gazeta.pl/kraj/1,34309,890904.html |date=2012-07-10 }}</ref> This event was widely reported by the media and, as a result, the Warsaw [[municipality]] decided to legalize future events, rather than escalate the conflict. Beginning in September 2002, Critical Mass events in Warsaw are organized in full cooperation with the police force. Once a year in August, beginning in 2007, a special Critical Mass is organized in cooperation with the city officials to commemorate the [[Warsaw Uprising]].
==Buenos Aires, Argentina== On March 28, 2013, in [[Buenos Aires, Argentina]], a taxi driver ran over a group of Critical Mass riders, injuring 2 cyclists, before fleeing from the scene.<ref>http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/sociedad/3-216870-2013-03-29.html</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
