{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Cornerstone Festival | image = [[Image:Cornerstone Festival.jpg|250px]] | caption = The Main Stage of Cornerstone. | location = [[Grayslake, Illinois]] (1984–1990)
[[Bushnell, Illinois]] (1990–2012) | years_active = 1984–2012 | founders = [[Jesus People USA]] | dates = | genre = [[Contemporary Christian music|CCM]], [[rock music|rock]], [[heavy metal music|metal]], [[punk music|punk]], [[pop music|pop]], [[rap music|rap]], [[folk music|folk]], [[electronic music|electronic]], [[Celtic music|Celtic]], [[country music|country]], [[hardcore punk|hardcore]] | website = {{URL|http://www.CornerstoneFestival.com}} }} '''Cornerstone Festival''' was a [[Christian music festival]] put on by [[Jesus People USA]] and held annually around July 4 near [[Bushnell, Illinois]], drawing some 20,000 attendees each year.{{cite web|author=Mark Moring |url=http://blog.christianitytoday.com/ctentertainment/2011/05/jesus-rally-planned-for-corner-1.html |title=Christianity Today Entertainment Blog: Jesus Rally Planned for Cornerstone |publisher=Blog.christianitytoday.com |date=May 25, 2011 |accessdate=September 22, 2014}} In a given year, many artists that played at Cornerstone also played at other events such as [[Creation Festival]] and mainstream festivals and tours such as the [[Warped Tour]]. The final festival was held in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.cornerstonefestival.com/information/specialAnnouncement.php |title=Cornerstone Festival 2012 :: Special Announcement |publisher=Cornerstonefestival.com |date=June 30, 2011 |accessdate=July 14, 2012}} Cornerstone Festival was a member of the [[Christian Festival Association]]. ==History== From 1984 to 1990, Cornerstone was held at the Lake County Fairgrounds near [[Grayslake, Illinois]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} In 1991, Cornerstone moved near the town of Bushnell (outside [[Macomb, Illinois|Macomb]]) where the organizers of the festival purchased a large piece of land, which is now called "Cornerstone Farm".{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} Tens of thousands of people attended Cornerstone Farm each year and saw over 300 bands play many styles of music, including [[rock and roll|rock]], [[heavy metal music|metal]], [[punk music|punk]], [[hardcore punk|hardcore]] and [[pop music]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} In addition to the many musicians, Cornerstone Festival also presented guest speakers, and featured independent/foreign film screenings, writers' seminars, and art workshops.{{cite web|author=Bushnell, Il [Yya] |url=http://oca.org/news/oca-news/cornerstone-2011-sharing-the-fullness-of-christ-at-cornerstone-music-festiv |title=News - CORNERSTONE 2011: Sharing the Fullness of Christ at Cornerstone Music Festival |publisher=OCA |date=July 20, 2011 |accessdate=May 16, 2014}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_3jqjSKHKcwC&pg=PA176&lpg=PA176 |title=Encyclopedia of Contemporary Christian Music: Pop, Rock, and Worship: Pop ... - Google Books |via=[[Google Books]]|accessdate=May 16, 2014}} In 2010 the festival's main stage moved to the "Midway", which is about 0.7 miles northeast of its previous location in the "bowl".{{cite web | url = http://www.cornerstonefestival.com/content.php?p=144#moving | title = Cornerstone Festival 2010 :: 10 Things You Need To Know About Cornerstone | accessdate =July 10, 2010 }} The 2011 festival featured a Jesus Rally showcasing many of the groundbreaking [[Jesus music]] artists including; [[Servant (band)|Servant]], [[Daniel Amos]], [[Randy Stonehill]], [[Barry McGuire]], [[Resurrection Band]], [[Phil Keaggy]], and [[Petra (band)|Classic Petra]].{{cite web|last=Trott |first=Jon |url=http://www.wilsonstation.com/cornerstone-festival-jesus-rally-celebrates-40-years-of-the-jesus-movement/ |title=Cornerstone Festival "Jesus Rally" Celebrates 40 Years of the Jesus Movement |publisher=Wilsonstation.com |date=May 26, 2012 |accessdate=May 16, 2014}}{{cite web|author=Mark Moring |url=http://blog.christianitytoday.com/ctentertainment/2011/05/jesus-rally-planned-for-corner-1.html |title=Christianity Today Entertainment Blog: Jesus Rally Planned for Cornerstone |publisher=Blog.christianitytoday.com |date=May 25, 2011 |accessdate=May 16, 2014}} On May 15, 2012 it was announced that the 2012 Festival will be the last.{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/notes/cornerstone-festival/a-special-announcement-from-cornerstone-festival/10150823717573549 |title=A Special Announcement From Cornerstone Festival |publisher=Facebook |accessdate=May 16, 2012}} The final song performed at Cornerstone, on July 7, 2012, was "To Bid Farewell" performed by [[Derri Daugherty]] and [[Steve Hindalong]] of [[The Choir (alternative rock band)|The Choir]].{{cite web|author=Becky |url=http://www.cornerstonefestival.com/blog/?p=1111 |title=Saturday – quick | |publisher=Cornerstonefestival.com |date=July 8, 2012 |accessdate=May 16, 2014}} == Books == * Young, Shawn David, "Hippies, Jesus Freaks, and Music" (Ann Arbor: Xanedu/Copley Original Works, 2005). {{ISBN|1-59399-201-7}} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|1=http://www.CornerstoneFestival.com}} * {{cite thesis|url=http://scholarcommons.usf.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=4367&context=etd |title=Constructing Alternative Christian Identities: An Ethnography of Jesus People USA's Cornerstone Festival |author=Brian Edward Johnston |accessdate=May 16, 2014| date=March 29, 2011}} {{Coord|40|31|53.00|N|90|26|12.00|W|display=title}} [[Category:Grayslake, Illinois]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in McDonough County, Illinois]] [[Category:Music festivals in Illinois]] established in 1984]] [[Category:Recurring events disestablished in 2012]]

page.title: Death and state funeral of Raúl Alfonsín

revision.comment: Bot: fix deprecated Citation Style 1 parameters ([[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/NihlusBOT 9|Task 9]])
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox event | title = <!-- Title to display, if other than page name --> | image = Raul Alfonsin Burial.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = People during the funeral of Alfonsín, at the Argentine Congress | native_name = | native_name_lang = | english_name = | time = | duration = 3 days | date = {{start date|2009|03|31}} | venue = [[Palace of the Argentine National Congress]], [[La Recoleta Cemetery]] | location = [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | also known as = | type = [[State funeral]] | theme = | cause = | first reporter = | budget = | patron = <!-- or |patrons= --> | organisers = <!-- or |organizers= --> | filmed by = | participants = | outcome = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | reported deaths = | reported injuries = | reported missing = | reported property damage = | burial = [[Raúl Alfonsín]] | inquiries = | inquest = | coroner = | arrests = | suspects = | accused = | convicted = | charges = | verdict = | convictions = | publication bans = | litigation = | awards = | blank_label = <!-- or |blank_data= --> | blank1_label = <!-- or |blank1_data= --> | blank2_label = <!-- or |blank2_data= --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | notes = }} [[Raúl Alfonsín]] was the [[president of Argentina]] from 1983 to 1989. He died on March 31, 2009, aged 82.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/01/world/americas/01alfonsin.html?ref=obituaries&_r=0|title= Raúl Alfonsín, 82, Former Argentine Leader, Dies|author= Clifford Kraus|date= 31 March 2009|work= The New York Times|accessdate=July 10, 2015}}</ref> He had lung cancer and died at his home; a massive candlelight vigil took place in the vicinity of it. Vice president [[Julio Cobos]], the acting president at the time, arranged three days of national mourning and a [[state funeral]] at the [[Palace of the Argentine National Congress]]. Alfonsín was seen by 40,000 people and the senior politicians of the country; people from other countries also voiced their respect for him. A military escort took his coffin to the [[La Recoleta Cemetery]], and left him at the pantheon for the veterans of the [[Revolution of the Park]].
==Health and death== Alfonsín had [[lung cancer]] for almost a year before his death, which led to [[pneumonia]]. His medic Alejandro Sandler explained that his health had worsened at several points, which were followed by brief recoveries. In his last days he was visited by vice president [[Julio Cobos]] and monsignor Justo Laguna, who gave him the [[Anointing of the Sick]]. He received [[home care]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.perfil.com/contenidos/2009/03/31/noticia_0010.html|title= Se agrava el estado de salud de Raúl Alfonsín: recibió a monseñor Laguna|trans-title=The health of Raúl Alfonsín gets worse: he received monsignor Laguna|language= Spanish|date= March 31, 2009|publisher= Perfil|accessdate=July 10, 2015}}</ref> as Sandler preferred him to stay with his family.<ref name="duelo3" /> The president [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] was out of the country and phoned several times; [[Ricardo Alfonsín]] called her at 17:00 and informed her of his father's health.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1113785-se-agravo-la-salud-de-raul-alfonsin|title= Se agravó la salud de Raúl Alfonsín|trans-title=The health of Raúl Alfonsín worsened|language= Spanish|date= March 31, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 13, 2015}}</ref> He died on March 31, 2009, at 20:30; Sandler announced it at 21:03. Alfonsín was sleeping at the moment, next to his family.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1113997-murio-quedandose-dormido-afirmo-su-medico|title= "Murió quedándose dormido", afirmó su médico|trans-title="He died falling asleep", said his medic|language= Spanish|date= March 31, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> Cobos was the first politician to arrive at his home.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.perfil.com/politica/Murio-Raul-Alfonsin-20090331-0029.html|title= Murió Raúl Alfonsín|trans-title=Raúl Alfonsín died|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|publisher= Perfil|accessdate=July 10, 2015}}</ref>
==Funeral== When the first news of the death of Alfonsín were released, the vicinity of his house at the [[Avenida Santa Fe|Santa Fe avenue]] was filled by hundreds of people, who started a [[Candlelight vigil]].<ref name="velas">{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114002-cientos-de-personas-se-congregan-en-la-casa-de-alfonsin|title= Cientos de personas se congregan en la casa de Alfonsín|trans-title=Hundreds of people gather at the house of Alfonsín|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> The multitude included friends, neighbors and political supporters. The politicians [[Felipe Solá]] and [[Ricardo Gil Lavedra]] attended the meeting as well. The balconies of nearby houses were filled with flowers and banners.<ref name="velas" /> [[File:Granaderos despedida alfonsín.jpg|thumb|left|Procession in the [[Callao Avenue]]]] The president Cristina Fernández de Kirchner was out of the country at the moment, and although she arranged an early return, she could not return to the country in time for the funeral.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114227-cristina-kirchner-adelanto-la-vuelta-de-londres|title= Cristina Kirchner adelantó la vuelta de Londres|trans-title=Cristina Kirchner speed up her return from London|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> As a result, the vice president Julio Cobos arranged the [[state funeral]] of Alfonsín, alongside [[Eduardo Fellner]] (president of the Chamber of deputies) and [[José Pampuro]] (acting president of the Senate). His widow, former [[First Lady of Argentina]] [[María Lorenza Barreneche]], was unable to attend her husband's public state funeral due to her own declining health.<ref name=clarin>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Murió María Lorenza Barrenechea, la esposa de Raúl Alfonsín |url=http://www.clarin.com/politica/Murio-Maria-Lorenza-Barrenechea-Alfonsi_0_1499250292.html |work=[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)]] |date=2016-01-06 |accessdate=2016-01-10}}</ref>
As a former Argentine president, his body was displayed at the Blue Hall of the [[Palace of the Argentine National Congress]]. He also set three days of national mourning, from March 31 to April 2. [[Daniel Scioli]], governor of the [[Buenos Aires Province]] (birthplace of Alfonsín), also announced a provincial mourning.<ref name="duelo3" /> Almost a thousand people attended, and at some moments they sang the [[Argentine National Anthem]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114109-un-homenaje-multitudinario-en-la-calle|title= Un homenaje multitudinario en la calle|trans-title=A populated homage in the streets|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref>
The people were allowed to enter to the Congress on April 1, 10:00.<ref name="duelo3">{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1113999-cobos-decreto-tres-dias-de-duelo-nacional|title= Cobos decretó tres días de Duelo Nacional|trans-title=Cobos decreed three days of national mourning|language= Spanish|date= March 31, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114076-sera-velado-en-el-congreso-a-partir-de-las-10|title= Será velado en el Congreso a partir de las 10|trans-title=He will be mourned in the Congress at 10:00|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref> Initially, it was intended to keep the Congress open until 20:00, but the number of people attending it forced to delay it for the morning of April 2.<ref name="continua">{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114216-continua-la-despedida-multitudinaria-de-alfonsin-en-el-congreso|title= Continúa la despedida multitudinaria de Alfonsín en el Congreso|trans-title=The populated goodbye to Alfonsín at the Congress continues|language= Spanish|date= April 2, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref> The event was attended by the former presidents [[Carlos Menem]], [[Fernando de la Rúa]], [[Eduardo Duhalde]] and [[Néstor Kirchner]], all the members of the [[Supreme Court of Argentina]], mayor [[Mauricio Macri]], governor Daniel Scioli, the president of Uruguay [[Tabaré Vázquez]] and several other politicians.<ref name="continua" /> The Congress was visited by almost 40,000 people.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114600-llantos-nostalgia-y-reclamos-en-el-emotivo-adios|title= Llantos, nostalgia y reclamos en el emotivo adiós|trans-title=Crying, nostalgia and petitions in the emotive last goodbye|language= Spanish|date= April 2, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 18, 2015}}</ref> It was the largest state funeral in Argentina since the death of [[Juan Perón]] in 1974.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114599-multitudinaria-despedida-a-alfonsin|title= Multitudinaria despedida a Alfonsín|trans-title=Multitudinarie last goodbye to Alfonsín|language= Spanish|author= Gustavo Ybarra|date= April 2, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 19, 2015}}</ref>
There was a ceremony afterwards with speeches from politicians from Alfonsín's tenure and from the Kirchner administration.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114678-emotivos-discursos-de-despedida-en-el-congreso|title= Emotivos discursos de despedida en el Congreso|trans-title=Emotive last goodbye speeches at the Congress|language= Spanish|date= April 2, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 18, 2015}}</ref> The ceremony was aired in ''[[cadena nacional]]''. It was followed by a mass given by [[José María Arancedo]], archbishop of Santa Fe. Finally, a procession in the [[Callao Avenue]] with a military escort took the corpse to the [[La Recoleta Cemetery]]. People threw flowers to the coffin, fly Argentine and radical flags, and sung the national anthem.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114651-tras-innumerables-expresiones-de-afecto-el-cuerpo-del-ex-presidente-descansa-en-recoleta|title= Tras innumerables expresiones de afecto, el cuerpo del ex presidente descansa en Recoleta|trans-title=After countless displays of affection, the corpse of the ex president lies in Recoleta|language= Spanish|date= April 3, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 19, 2015}}</ref> He was left in the pantheon for the veterans of the [[Revolution of the Park]], until he got a special one for himself.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114216-continua-la-despedida-multitudinaria-de-alfonsin-en-el-congreso|title= Continúa la despedida multitudinaria de Alfonsín en el Congreso|trans-title=The miltutudinarie goodbye to Alfonsín at the Congress continues|language= Spanish|date= April 2, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref>
Twenty-two Argentine bishops at the [[Holy See]] held a mass for Alfonsín as well. It was at the [[Archbasilica of St. John Lateran]], and was attended by the Argentine ambassador [[Juan Pablo Cafiero]], the Italian monsignor Giuseppe Laterza and the Argentine monsignor Guillermo Karcher. The bishops met [[Pope Benedict XVI]] the following day.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114346-italia-obispos-argentinos-celebraron-una-misa-por-el-lider-radical|title= Italia: obispos argentinos celebraron una misa por el líder radical|trans-title=Italy: Argentine bishops held a mass for the radical leader|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref>
==Reactions== [[File:Condolenciasobama.jpg|thumb|Message of condolences sent by [[Barack Obama]], president of the United States]] The living former presidents of Argentina sent their condolences for Alfonsín. [[Carlos Menem]] said that his death was a great loss for democracy.<ref name="expresi">{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114067-ex-presidentes-manifestaron-su-pesar-por-el-adios-de-un-hombre-de-la-democracia|title= Ex presidentes manifestaron su pesar por el adiós de un hombre "de la democracia"|trans-title=Ex presidents manifested their sorrow for the goodbye to a man of democracy|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> He also wrote an editorial for the ''[[La Nación]]'' newspaper, titled "Un viejo adversario saluda a un amigo" ({{lang-es|link=no|An old adversary salutes a friend}}), mirroring the famous quotation of the radical leader [[Ricardo Balbín]] during the funeral of Perón.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114525-un-viejo-adversario-saluda-a-un-amigo|title= Un viejo adversario saluda a un amigo|trans-title=An old adversary salutes a friend|language= Spanish|author= Carlos Menem|date= April 2, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 19, 2015}}</ref> [[Fernando de la Rúa]] said that "he fought all his life for politics and democracy. He raised up the values of democracy. Respect and affection were always present in him".<ref name="expresi" /> [[Eduardo Duhalde]] described him as a family friend,<ref name="expresi" /> and said Argentina lost a great man.<ref name="saludo">{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114219-el-ultimo-saludo-de-referentes-politicos|title= El último saludo de referentes políticos|trans-title=The last goodbye of political leaders|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref> [[Néstor Kirchner]] praised the [[trial of the Juntas]].<ref name="expresi" /> He also received condolences of [[José Sarney]], [[Patricio Aylwin]] and [[Julio María Sanguinetti]], contemporary presidents of Brazil, Chile and Uruguay.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114139-los-ex-presidentes|title= Los ex presidentes|trans-title=The ex presidents|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> The governments of Brazil, Chile, Colombia, France, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru, Spain, United States and Uruguay also sent messages of condolences.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114221-lideres-mundiales-envian-sus-condolencias|title= Líderes mundiales envían sus condolencias|trans-title=Global leaders send their condolences|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref>
[[Ricardo López Murphy]], minister of economy of president Fernando de la Rúa, said that Alfonsín was "the man who fought for our democracy and the strengthening of institutions, during a time of conflicts and polarizations that our society was merged into".<ref name="pesar">{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114003-profundo-pesar-en-el-ambito-politico-por-la-muerte-del-ex-presidente|title= Profundo pesar en el ámbito político por la muerte del ex presidente|trans-title=Deep pain in politics for the death of the ex-president|language= Spanish|date= April 1, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> [[Cristian Ritondo]], legislator of the [[Republican Proposal]], said that "Alfonsín was the main actor of the return of democracy to Argentina. He was a sinonym of work, responsibility and patriotism".<ref name="pesar" /> [[Gerardo Morales (politician)|Gerardo Morales]] said that "when we were young in 1983 and sang 'we are life, we are peace', it was more than a slogan, it was a synthesis of our hopes: do not suffer more persecutions, live in democracy, in freedom and peace. We were part of the collective project led by Alfonsín".<ref name="pesar" /> [[Elisa Carrió]] pointed that she had political disputes with him, but respected him nonetheless.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1114008-carrio-marco-una-generacion|title= Carrió: "Marcó una generación"|trans-title=Carrió: "He marked a whole generation"|language= Spanish|date= March 31, 2009|work= La Nación|accessdate=August 12, 2015}}</ref> [[Julio César Strassera]], judge of the trial of the juntas, hoped that Alfonsín would be remembered as a great democrat.<ref name="saludo" /> [[Daniel Scioli]], governor of the Buenos Aires province, praised that he died with a complete peace of mind.<ref name="saludo" /> [[Mauricio Macri]], mayor of Buenos Aires, considered that he must have died in peace, after fulfilling his goals.<ref name="saludo" />
