revision.comment: Undid unsourced claim, with errors, inserted between existing text and its citation, which it broke.
revision.text:
The '''long-term complications of standing''' are the conditions that may arise after prolonged time in a standing or upright position including standing, walking or running. Many of the complications come from prolonged standing (more the 60% of a work day) that is repeated several times a week. There are many different jobs that require prolonged standing. These included: "retail staff, Baristas, bartenders, assembly line workers, security staff, engineers, catering staff, library assistants, hair stylists and laboratory technicians."<ref name="safeworkers.co.uk">{{cite web|last1=Watson|first1=Kevin|title=MSc|url=http://www.safeworkers.co.uk/standing-for-long-periods.html|website=Standing for Long Periods|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref>
Cornell university has calculated that "Standing requires ~20% more energy than sitting".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cornell University|title=Sitting and Standing at Work|url=http://ergo.human.cornell.edu/CUESitStand.html}}</ref>
==Prevalence== There are no exact measures of how prevalent the complications are. However, European studies report that between one third and one half of all workers spend at least four hours per [[Working time]] (for an average workday of eight hours) standing or walking.<ref name=whsc>[http://www.whsc.on.ca/Files/Resources/Hazard-Resource-Lines/Prolonged-Standing-WHSC-Resource-Line Prolonged Standing: taking the load off], Version 2.0. From: Workers Health and Safety Center.</ref> One estimate from the United Kingdom stated that over 11 million people stand for long periods of time without rest.<ref name="safeworkers.co.uk"/>
==Complications==
===Slouching=== {{see also|Kyphosis}} Proper posture is often referred to as a "[[neutral spine]]"; slouching is an improper posture or a "nonneutral spine"
Slouching is often times described as improper posture, movement or rigidity of the spine, especially the cervical and thoracic regions, in relation to other parts of the body.
===Varicose veins=== [[Varicose veins]] are veins that have become enlarged and twisted, especially within the legs, ankles and feet of an affected individual.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/varicose-veins/basics/definition/con-20043474 |title=Diseases and Conditions: Varicose veins |author=Mayo Clinic Staff |publisher=[[Mayo Clinic]] |accessdate=December 22, 2015}}</ref>
When standing, gravity pulls the blood downwards to the lower part of the body. Body mechanisms, such as [[vasoconstriction]] and valves of the [[veins]], assist in pumping blood upwards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sirweb.org/patients/varicose-veins/|title=Society of Interventional Radiology- Patient center|author=|date=|work=SIRweb.org|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> As blood is pumped through the body, the valves within the veins prevent the blood from flowing backwards. After extensive, prolonged standing, these valves can become weak and eventually fail. When this happens, blood is no longer being prevented from flowing backward. Gravity will pull the blood back into an individuals legs, ankles and feet. This forces the veins to expand or "balloon" to accommodate this extra blood.
The valves of the [[veins]] work best in concert with accompanying muscle contractions that force the blood to continue moving up the leg. Standing with some muscles constantly strained weakens these muscles and therefore the strength of the contractions. Varicose veins have also been associated with chronic heart and circulatory disorders and hypertension as well as complications related to pregnancy.
Prolonged standing increases the risk for hospitalization from varicose veins.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tuchsen|first1=F|title=Prolonged standing at work and hospitalization due to varicose veins: a 12 year prospective study of the Danish population.|journal=Occup Environ Med|date=2005|volume=62|pages=847–850}}</ref> Among the working age population one out of five hospitalizations from varicose veins are as a result of prolonged standing. Prolonged standing leads to impeded blood flow and stasis in the veins in the lower limbs, which can cause varicose veins.
===Cardiovascular disorders=== Standing for prolonged periods can lead to certain cardiovascular disorders. In a study by Krause et al. (2000)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Krause|first1=N|title=Standing at work and progression of carotid atherosclerosis|journal=Scandinavian Journal of Work, Environment & Health|date=2000|pages=227–236|doi=10.5271/sjweh.536|volume=26|issue=3}}</ref> the authors examined the relationship between standing at work and the progression of carotid [[atherosclerosis]] in men. Standing for long periods can change the distribution of blood in the extremities. This in turn causes the blood to pool and reduces the circulating blood plasma volume leading to hemodynamic changes that impact the body. The authors reported that long periods of standing at work were significantly associated with atherosclerotic progression. This study provides evidence that hemodynamic changes from standing can influence the progressions of carotid atherosclerosis. The authors also found that men with carotid stenosis or ischemic heart disease were at greater risk for the progression of atherosclerosis . Atherosclerosis can lead to coronary artery disease, carotid artery disease, peripheral artery disease, and aneurysms.<ref>http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/arteriosclerosis-atherosclerosis/basics/complications/con-20026972</ref>
===Joint compression=== Standing places significant pressure on the joint of the hips, knees, ankle and feet but without any significant movement of it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hazards.org/standing/|title=Standing - Hazards Magazine|author=|date=|work=Hazards.org|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> This reduces the normal lubrication and cushioning of synovial joints, causing them to tear. The combined effect of pressure and tearing can cause extensive amounts of pain and make it difficult to move or walk.<ref name=whsc/>
===Muscle fatigue=== Muscles kept in a constant stress position quickly become exhausted and can result in pain and swelling in the lower back, legs, ankles and feet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.safeworkers.co.uk/standing-for-long-periods.html|title=Standing for Long Periods|author=|date=|work=SafeWorkers.co.uk|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/rnj.166/abstract|title=Evidence of Health Risks Associated with Prolonged Standing at Work and Intervention Effectiveness|first1=Thomas R.|last1=Waters|first2=Robert B.|last2=Dick|date=1 May 2015|publisher=|journal=Rehabil Nurs|volume=40|issue=3|pages=148–165|accessdate=23 February 2017|via=Wiley Online Library|doi=10.1002/rnj.166|pmid=25041875| pmc=4591921}}</ref>
The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) has stated that muscle fatigue and musculoskeletal disorders account for "33% of all worker injury and illness".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/SLTC/ergonomics/|title=Safety and Health Topics - Ergonomics - Occupational Safety and Health Administration|author=|date=|work=OSHA.gov|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> Considerable research has been conducted as to the extent of muscle injuries and all have concluded that these are expected but can be reduced with breaks and the availability of chairs.{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}}
Research has shown that the body experiences muscle fatigue after standing for five hours; this fatigue persists for more than 30 minutes after the end of the work day according to electronic measurements of fatigue.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Garcia|first1=M|title=Longterm muscle fatigue after standing work|journal=Human Factors|date=2015|volume=57|issue=7|pages=1162–1173|doi=10.1177/0018720815590293}}</ref> The perception of fatigue is subjective and does not necessarily correlate with the experimental indicators of fatigue.
==Pregnancy== Walking or standing more than six hours per day has been linked with pre-term births, low birth weights as well as high blood pressure for the mother.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/247272.php|title=Prolonged Standing During Pregnancy May Result In Stunted Fetal Growth|author=|date=|work=MedicalNewsToday.com|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref>
Researchers have found that working more than 25 hours a week has been "associated with slower rates of fetal growth". They also found that, on average, there are no "negative effects of working up to 36 weeks into pregnancy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livescience.com/36507-pregnancy-working-baby-growth.html|title=Standing for Long Hours During Pregnancy May Slow Babies' Growth|author=|date=|work=LiveScience.com|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref>
==Productivity== A systematic review from Karakolis and Callaghan<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Karakolis|first1=T|title=The impact of sitstand office workstations on worker discomfort and productivity: a review|journal=Applied Ergonomics|volume=45|issue=3|pages=799–806|doi=10.1016/j.apergo.2013.10.001|pmid=24157240|year=2014}}</ref> found that sit-stand workstations did not reduce worker productivity. Three of the reviewed studies found increased productivity when workers used sit stand stations, four reported no impact on the productivity of workers, and one reported mixed results.
==Intervention== There is no real prevention for standing, but there are ways to mitigate time spent standing in the workplace. Experts suggest to move around and change positions throughout the day. It is best not to sit in one position for more than 20 minutes, or to stand in one position for more than 8 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/health-wellness/2014/11/03/yes-sitting-work-bad-but-standing-actually-better/7ceei6fb0B7QjgAH3FlOrK/story.html|title=Yes sitting at work is bad, but is standing actually better? - The Boston Globe|author=|date=|work=BostonGlobe.com|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref>
If prolonged sitting in the workplace is required or desired, individuals should gradually transition to significant periods of standing.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Buckley|first1=J.P.|title=The sedentary office: a growing case for change toward better health and productivity. Expert statement commissioned by Public Health England and the Active Working Community Interest Company|journal=Br J Sports Med|date=2015|volume=49|issue=21|pages=1357–62|doi=10.1136/bjsports-2015-094618|pmid=26034192}}</ref> When transitioning from sitting to standing, individuals might experience musculoskeletal discomfort or fatigue while the body adapts.
Companies should design workstations that are conducive to good health. Workstations should allow workers to choose between several working positions and to move easily between them.<ref name="ccohs.ca">{{cite web|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/ergonomics/standing/standing_basic.html|title=Working in a Standing Position - Basic Information : OSH Answers|first=Government of Canada, Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and|last=Safety|date=|work=CCOHS.ca|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> Additionally, workers should be able to adjust the height of their workstations to fit their body size. Other helpful aspects of workstations are footrests, elbow rests, and seats so workers can sit when they need to.
==Footwear==
The choice of footwear can change the impact of prolonged standing. Shoes should support the foot, have shock-absorbing cushions, fit the foot well, and be comfortable.<ref name="ccohs.ca"/> Shoes should not be flat, have heels higher than 5 cm, or change the shape of the foot. There are also special insoles for shoes that can be used when soft mats or chairs are not available. Additionally the floors in a work area should not be metal or concrete. It is best to have cork or rubber covered floors. Floors should not be slippery.
Training and education are important components of avoiding complications from standing. Employees trained in ergonomics experience less muscle discomfort and more productivity while using sit-stand work stations than workers not trained.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Robertson,|first1=M.M.|title=Office ergonomics training and a sitstand workstation: Effects on musculoskeletal and visual symptoms and performance of office workers|journal=Applied Ergonomics|volume=44|issue=1|pages=73–85|doi=10.1016/j.apergo.2012.05.001|pmid=22727324|date=January 2013}}</ref>
==Floor mats==
Proper floor mats can also be used to reduce stress on feet and knees. Anti-fatigue matting is recommended and launderable matting is preferred.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} A study investigating the effects of 4 different standing conditions on assembly workers showed that using mats and shoes with in-soles was perceived as more comfortable for the workers than without while standing on hard floors.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=12236657|title=A comparison of the effects of floor mats and shoe in-soles on standing fatigue|journal=Applied ergonomics|volume=33|issue=5|pages=477–84|last=|first=|date=|website=|year=2002|author1=King|first1=P. M}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Neutral spine]] * [[Varicose veins]] * [[Ergonomics]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Long-Term Complications Of Standing}} [[Category:Injuries]] [[Category:Spinal cord]] [[Category:Physical exercise]] [[Category:Ergonomics]]

'''Marc Garlasco''' (born September 4, 1970) is an American former Pentagon senior intelligence analyst, now senior civilian protection officer for the [[United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan]] (UNAMA) and senior military advisor for the [[Human Rights Council]] (HRC). Having served for seven years at the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]], becoming chief of high-value targeting,<ref name=spiegel /> Garlasco left in 2003 and joined [[Human Rights Watch]] (HRW) as a senior military expert, specializing in [[battle]] damage assessment, military operations, and interrogations for the Emergencies Division, where he investigated [[human rights]] issues in a number of different conflicts zones. The author of a [[World War II]] German anti-aircraft medals reference book, Garlasco was suspended by HRW with pay, "pending an investigation", on September 14, 2009 after it was alleged that he had collected [[Nazi]] memorabilia.<ref name="israelis_see_NYT"/><ref name=NPR>Flintoff, C. (September 16, 2009). "Rights Analyst Suspended Over Nazi-Era Collection," National Public Radio. https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=112900014&ft=1&f=1001</ref> Garlasco downplayed the controversy, indicating he collected German and US World War II memorabilia because of family history and his interest in military history.<ref name="Huff-2009-09-11" /><ref name="google.com">[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gN0ozL3Zpc5Wv8369sfOpffXmA6Q AFP, "Rights group suspends analyst over Nazi collection"]</ref> He resigned from HRW in February 2010.<ref name=jpquit/> He served as senior civilian protection officer for UNAMA in 2011,<ref name="unmissions1">{{cite web|title=Today's Afghan Headlines|url=http://unama.unmissions.org/Default.aspx?tabid=4647&ctl=Details&mid=5294&ItemID=14663|publisher=UNAMA|accessdate=13 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325220740/http://unama.unmissions.org/Default.aspx?tabid=4647|archive-date=2012-03-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> heading the UN's Protection of Civilians office.<ref name="washingtonpost1">{{cite news|title=NATO's lost lessons from Libya|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/natos-lost-lessons-from-libya/2012/06/11/gJQAhkAoVV_story.html|accessdate=13 June 2012|newspaper=Washington Post|date=11 June 2012}}</ref> In early 2012, as the U.N. senior military advisor for the HRC's [[Independent Commission of Inquiry]] on [[Libya]], he investigated civilian casualties while leading a survey of [[NATO|NATO's]] [[Operation Unified Protector|activities in Libya]].<ref name="washingtonpost1"/>
==Career==
Garlasco has a B.A. in Government from [[Saint John's University (New York)|St. John's University]] 1988 — 1992 and an M.A. in International Relations from the [[Elliott School of International Affairs]] at the [[George Washington University]](1992–1995)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/bios/marc-garlasco|title=People|access-date=2016-08-26}}</ref> He lives in Pleasantville, New York.<ref name=spiegel>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,617279,00.html |title=The Pentagon Official Who Came in From the Cold |last=Koelbl |first=Susanne |date=2009-04-03 |publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE |accessdate=2009-10-01}} </ref> Garlasco was the senior military analyst in Human Rights Watch's (HRW) Emergencies Division. He specialized in battle damage assessment, military operations, and interrogations.<ref name=guardian_profile/>
===The Pentagon=== He worked with a defense contractor<ref name="WP-2008-02-13">White, Josh (2008-02-13). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/12/AR2008021202692.html The Man on Both Sides of Air War Debate]. ''The Washington Post''. Retrieved 2009-09-09.</ref> before being hired as an intelligence professional at the [[Defense Intelligence Agency]] working in the Pentagon; he survived the 9/11 attack on the building.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=90716538|title=The Pentagon on Sept. 11: One Survivor's Account|access-date=2016-08-26}}</ref> He claims he was Chief of [[High-value target]]ing in [[The Pentagon]] during the [[Iraq War|Second Gulf War]]<ref name=guardian_profile/> where he claimed to lead the effort to track and target [[Saddam Hussein]]. The initial targets and attack, known as the "DECAP strike", was identified by the CIA and the actual attacks were planned by TLAM and F-117 (see:[[2003 invasion of Iraq#Opening salvo: the Dora Farms strike|Dora Farms]]). Garlasco was a member of the [[Operation Desert Fox]] (Iraq) [[Bomb damage assessment|Battle Damage Assessment]] team in 1998, led a Pentagon Battle Damage Assessment team to [[Kosovo]] in 1999 and recommended several thousand aimpoints on targets during military operations in Iraq and [[1999 NATO bombing of Yugoslavia|Serbia]].<ref name=guardian_profile/> Later that year Garlasco debriefed Iraqi nationals to gather intelligence about Saddam Hussein. He described it as "contingency planning for a war that was probably never going to be fought."<ref name="WP-2008-02-13"/> He also participated in over 50 interrogations as a subject matter expert.<ref name=guardian_profile>[http://commentisfree.guardian.co.uk/marc_garlasco/profile.html Marc Garlasco profile at guardian.co.uk]</ref> In total, Garlasco served for seven years in [[the Pentagon]].<ref name=guardian_profile />
In 2003, Garlasco was responsible for dropping two, laser-guided, 500-kilogram bombs on a house in the Tuwaisi, neighborhood of [[Basra]], Iraq, that he believed to contain Saddam Hussein's cousin [[Ali Hassan al-Majid]], also known as Chemical Ali, the man responsible for launching poison gas attacks on Kurds in Iraq beginning in 1988.<ref name=spiegel /> Watching the attack via satellite form a room in the Pentagon, Garlasco threw his arms in the air and shouted: "I just blew up Chemical Ali!" However, Chemical Ali was not in the house; 17 other people were killed instead.<ref name=spiegel /> Garlasco left his Pentagon job in 2003 two weeks after the failed attack<ref name="WP-2008-02-13"/> to take a position as senior military analyst at Human Rights Watch.<ref name=cbs_60min />
Garlasco explained the calculus of civilian deaths in high-value targeting to the television news program [[60 Minutes]] this way, "Our number was 30. So, for example, Saddam Hussein. If you're gonna kill up to 29 people in a strike against Saddam Hussein, that's not a problem. But once you hit that number 30, we actually had to go to either President Bush, or Secretary of Defense Rumsfeld." Garlasco told the interviewer that prior to the invasion of Iraq, he personally recommended 50 high-value targets for air strikes, but, according to Garlasco, none of the targets on his list was actually killed. Rather, "a couple of hundred civilians at least" were killed in strikes he recommended.<ref name=cbs_60min /> Garlasco defended the efforts made by the American military to minimize civilian casualties, "I don't think people really appreciate the gymnastics that the U.S. military goes through in order to make sure that they're not killing civilians".<ref name=cbs_60min>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/10/25/60minutes/main3411230_page2.shtml Bombing Afghanistan, Afghan President Tells 60 Minutes That Too Many Civilians Are Being Killed], Aug. 31, 2008, CBS News, 60 Minutes</ref> He responded to the question "If so much care is being taken why are so many civilians getting killed?" by stating "Because the Taliban are violating international law, and because the U.S. just doesn't have enough troops on the ground. You have the Taliban shielding in people's homes. And you have this small number of troops on the ground. And sometimes the only thing they can do is drop bombs."<ref name=cbs_60min />
===Human Rights Watch=== After leaving the Pentagon, Garlasco joined [[Human Rights Watch]] as a senior military analyst; his task was to document [[War crimes|laws-of-war violations]] and other atrocities committed during significant conflicts around the world. In an interview he gave for the [[Washington Post]] Garlasco described the transition from targeter to human rights advocate; "I had been a part of it, so it was a lot harder than I thought it would be. It really dawned on me that these aren't just nameless, faceless targets. This is a place where people are going to feel ramifications for a long time."<ref name="WP-2008-02-13" />
In December 2003, Garlasco co-authored the report 'Off Target - The Conduct of the War and Civilian Casualties in Iraq' after carrying out field work with two other HRW staff to investigate the effect of the [[air war]], [[ground war]], and the immediate post-combat environment on civilians after the fall of Baghdad to U.S. led Coalition forces in the [[Iraq War]].<ref name="HRW-OffTarget-ACK">{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/node/12207/section/15 |title=Off Target - ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS |date=2003-12-11 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=2009-09-16}} </ref><ref name="HRW-OffTarget-SUM">{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/node/12207/section/5 |title=Off Target - I. SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS |date=2003-12-11 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=2009-09-16}} </ref> Garlasco and colleagues focused on the main fighting areas in the [[Tigris]] and [[Euphrates]] river valleys where civilian deaths had been reported, visiting ten cities in total.<ref name="HRW-OffTarget-SUM"/> The report focused on the identification and investigation of potential violations of international humanitarian law by both Coalition and Iraqi forces together with the identification of patterns of conflict which may have resulted in avoidable civilian casualties. <ref name="HRW-OffTarget-SUM"/> Garlasco and his co-author stated that Iraqi forces had committed various violations of international humanitarian law which may have resulted in significant civilian casualties and claimed that the widespread use of [[cluster munitions]] in populated areas by Coalition forces killed or wounded more than 1,000 civilians.<ref name="HRW-OffTarget">{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2003/12/11/target-0 |title=Off Target - The Conduct of the War and Civilian Casualties in Iraq |date=2003-12-11 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=2009-09-16}} </ref>
In October 2004, Garlasco co-authored the report 'Razing Rafah: Mass Home Demolitions in the Gaza Strip' after carrying out research with two other HRW staff in the [[Gaza Strip]], [[Israel]], and [[Egypt]].<ref name="HRW-RazingRafah-ACK">{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/node/11963/section/20 |title=Razing Rafah - ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS |date=2004-10-17 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=2009-09-28}} </ref><ref name="HRW-RazingRafah-SUM">{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/node/11963/section/3 |title=Razing Rafah - I. SUMMARY |date=2004-10-17 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=2009-09-28}} </ref> The report documented what it described as a "pattern of illegal demolitions" by the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] in [[Rafah]], a refugee camp and city at the southern end of the Gaza Strip on the border with Egypt where sixteen thousand people lost their homes after the Israeli government approved a plan to expand the de facto [[Philadelphi Route|"buffer zone"]] in May 2004.<ref name="HRW-RazingRafah-SUM"/><ref name="HRW-RazingRafah">{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2004/10/17/razing-rafah-0|title=Razing Rafah |date=2004-10-17 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=2009-09-29}} </ref> Garlasco and colleagues examined the background to and effects of the demolitions, the security situation in Rafah, the IDF's main stated rationales for the demolitions, responding to and preventing attacks on its forces and the suppression of weapons smuggling through tunnels from Egypt,<ref name="HRW-RazingRafah-SEC">{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/node/11963/section/7 |title=Razing Rafah - IV. THE SECURITY SITUATION IN RAFAH |date=2004-10-17 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=2009-09-28}} </ref> and concluded that in most cases the demolitions were "carried out in the absence of military necessity" in violation of international law.<ref name="HRW-RazingRafah-SUM"/>
Garlasco has made it a personal objective to prevent the use of cluster munitions.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/12/AR2008021202692.html | work=The Washington Post | title=The Man on Both Sides of Air War Debate | first=Josh | last=White | date=2008-02-13 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> He co-authored the 2006 [[Human Rights Watch]] report condemning [[Israel]]'s use of such weapons in [[Lebanon]] and a report in 2008 documenting how civilians living in [[South Ossetia]] suffered the use of cluster munitions by both the [[Russia]]n and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] armies.<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2008/02/16/flooding-south-lebanon-0 Flooding South Lebanon: Israel's Use of Cluster Munitions in Lebanon in July and August 2006]. Human Rights Watch, 2/16/08</ref><ref>[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2009/04/14/dying-practice-0 A Dying Practice: Use of Cluster Munitions by Russian and Georgia in August 2008]. Human Rights Watch, 4/14/09</ref> Colin Kahl, a professor of security studies at Georgetown University, said that Garlasco "knows more about airstrikes than anyone in the world who isn't in the military currently", adding that "when Marc says stuff is messed up, the military has to take it seriously. It's not some wing nut in a human rights group out to get the military".<ref name="WP-2008-02-13" />
According to [[Haaretz]], Garlasco worked in the Pentagon for seven years and "was known over the last years of his career for his harsh condemnation of Israel".<ref name= haaretz_1113>[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1113728.html Former HRW analyst said to be avid collector of Nazi souvenirs], Haaretz, Sept. 10, 2009</ref>
John H. Richardson, a writer at ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'', writes that Garlasco's work on torture scandals in Iraq resulted in testimony from American soldiers that led directly to [[John McCain]]'s anti-torture [[Detainee Treatment Act|amendment]]. Richardson also writes that Garlasco was one of the first foreigners to cross the border into Georgia during its war with Russia, and that during the [[Gaza War (2008–09)|Gaza War]] Garlasco lived in an apartment in the middle of the war zone and spent weeks visiting hospitals and bomb sites.<ref name=Esquire>Richardson, John."[http://www.esquire.com/the-side/richardson-report/marc-garlasco-nazi-controversy-101309 Why Is This Good Man Getting Hung Out to Dry?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091015073334/http://www.esquire.com/the-side/richardson-report/marc-garlasco-nazi-controversy-101309 |date=2009-10-15 }}" ''Esquire'' (Oct 2009). Accessed October 14, 2009.</ref>
Garlasco has attracted some criticism for his reporting, with the ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]'', for example, suggesting in an editorial that he "has made a career of painting Israel as a criminal state".<ref>[https://ottawacitizen.com/opinion/secret+motives/1998271/story.html ''Not-so-secret motives'', Ottawa Citizen], September 16, 2009 (retrieved September 22, 2009)</ref>
Garlasco appeared as an expert in the documentary film ''[[No End in Sight]]'', which examined in detail some of the key decisions made by the US military and the Pentagon in the early days after the invasion of Iraq.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ferguson|first=Charles|title=No end in sight: Iraq's descent into chaos|publisher=PublicAffairs|year=2008|page=9|isbn=978-1-58648-608-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RReuw-_oCzoC&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9#v=onepage&q=&f=false}}</ref> He was also featured in a ''[[60 Minutes]]'' story on US military targeting practices that aired October 28, 2007.<ref name=cbs_60min />
Emma Daly confirmed in March 2010 that Garlasco resigned from Human Rights Watch in February 2010, and offered no elaboration.<ref name=jpquit>[http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=170313 After ‘Post' query, HRW says top military analyst quit, Jerusalem Post], (retrieved March 5, 2010)</ref>
===United Nations=== Beginning in 2011, Garlasco served as senior civilian protection officer for [[United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan]] (UNAMA).<ref name="unmissions1"/> Heading the UN's Protection of Civilians office, Garlasco monitored civilian casualty rates, and admonished Taliban leader [[Mullah Mohammad Omar]] to refrain from using [[Land mine|mine]]s.<ref name="unmissions1"/> In early 2012, as the U.N. senior military advisor for the [[Human Rights Council]]'s (HRC) [[Independent Commission of Inquiry]] on [[Libya]], he investigated civilian casualties while leading a survey of [[NATO]]'s [[Operation Unified Protector|activities in Libya]].<ref name="washingtonpost1"/>
==Suspension from HRW over Nazi memorabilia==
On September 14, 2009 Garlasco was suspended with pay after a controversy arose regarding when it was publicized that he collects Nazi memorabilia.<ref name="israelis_see_NYT"/><ref name=NPR /> Criticism that had started to appear, posted by what the Guardian called Pro-Israeli bloggers, had questioned the appropriateness of Garlasco's hobby.<ref name=guardian_allegations /> Garlasco has stated his hobby of collecting German and American World War memorabilia from the Second World War is because of his family history and his interest in military history.
===Initial controversy=== On September 9, 2009 ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' quoted blogger [[Omri Ceren]] saying that Garlasco is "obsessed with the color and pageantry of Nazism, has published a detailed 430-page book on Nazi war paraphernalia, and participates in forums for Nazi souvenir collectors".<ref name="JP=2009-09-09">[http://www.jpost.com/Israel/HRW-expert-collects-Nazi-memorabilia 'HRW expert collects Nazi memorabilia'], JPost, September 09 2009</ref> Other newspapers such as ''[[The Guardian]]'' and ''[[Haaretz]]'' covered the controversy in the following days.<ref name= haaretz_1113 /><ref name=guardian_allegations />
''[[The Guardian]]'' reported on what it described as "mounting internet attacks on Garlasco". Pro-Israeli bloggers had questioned the appropriateness of Garlasco's hobby and discovered one blogpost in which Garlasco wrote, "The leather [[Uniforms and insignia of the Schutzstaffel|SS jacket]] makes my blood go cold it is so COOL!"<ref name=guardian_allegations>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/10/human-rights-watch-israel-nazi |title=Human Rights Watch investigator accused of collecting Nazi memorabilia; Watchdog organisation has had tension with Israeli government over criticism of military actions in Gaza |last=Pilkington |first=Ed |date=2009-09-10 |publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-09-12 | location=London}} </ref>
Israeli Prime Minister [[Binyamin Netanyahu|Benyamin Netanyahu]]'s policy director commented that Human Rights Watch's employment of "a man who trades and collects Nazi memorabilia" as its senior military expert is a "new low".<ref name="JP=2009-09-09"/>
=== HRW response === Though Garlasco initially responded to the allegations under the pen name Flak88,<ref name=maariv /> writing "I would reply, but I don't want to encourage them... Anyway, I doubt if they read my book. More than anything else, it is related to my work." <ref name="maariv">[http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART1/940/098.html?hp=1&loc=31&tmp=7486 Maariv], Sept. 9, 2009, English translation available here [http://www.imra.org.il/story.php3?id=45684]</ref> He subsequently apologized, writing on [[Huffington Post]], "I deeply regret causing pain and offense with a handful of juvenile and tasteless postings I made on two websites that study Second World War artifacts". Garlasco added, "I've never hidden my hobby, because there's nothing shameful in it, however weird it might seem to those who aren't fascinated by military history". He also wrote that the allegations of Nazi sympathies were "defamatory nonsense, spread maliciously by people with an interest in trying to undermine Human Rights Watch's reporting," and that "I work to expose war crimes and the Nazis were the worst war criminals of all time". He added, "[p]recisely because it's so obvious that the Nazis were evil, I never realized that other people, including friends and colleagues, might wonder why I care about these things". He went on to say that "I told my daughters, as I wrote in my book, that "the war was horrible and cruel, that Germany lost and for that we should be thankful".<ref name="Huff-2009-09-11">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/marc-garlasco/human-rights-watch-invest_b_284075.html |title=Responding to Accusations |last=Garlasco |first=Marc |date=2009-09-11 |publisher=The Huffington Post |accessdate=2009-09-13}} </ref>
HRW Communications Director Emma Daly at first responded to the charge by saying, "Marc Garlasco is not pro-Nazi. These allegations are monstrous. He does not delve into Nazi memorabilia. Garlasco is a student of military history and he has an interest in military history". HRW later issued an official statement that the accusation against Garlasco "is demonstrably false and fits into a campaign to deflect attention from Human Rights Watch's rigorous and detailed reporting on violations of international human rights and humanitarian law by the Israeli government," adding that Garlasco "has never held or expressed Nazi or [[anti-Semitic]] views".<ref name="HRW-2009-09-10">{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/node/85545 |title=Protecting Civilians: Military Expert Marc Garlasco |date=2009-09-10 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=2009-09-11}} </ref> HRW associate director Carroll Bogert accused ''The Guardian'' of "repeat[ing] defamatory nonsense unworthy of [the] newspaper," adding that "[t]he allegations of pro-Nazi sympathies are part of a larger campaign to smear non-governmental organisations which criticise the Israel Defense Forces' conduct of the Gaza offensive".<ref name="G-2009-09-12">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/12/human-rights-israel |title=Unfair attack on Marc Garlasco (Letter)|last=Bogert|first=Carroll |date=2009-09-12 |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=2009-09-12 | location=London}} </ref> Iain Levine, the watchdog's programme director responded by saying that "The Israeli government is trying to eliminate the space for legitimate criticism of the conduct of the IDF, and this is the latest salvo in that campaign".<ref name="guardian.co.uk">[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/15/human-rights-watch-nazi-israel ''The Guardian'' "Human Rights Watch investigator suspended over Nazi memorabilia," September 15, 2009]</ref>
In what has been described by Ed Pilkington of ''The Guardian'' as an "abrupt change of tact" (''sic'') for Human Rights Watch,<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/> Garlasco was "suspended with pay" from HRW pending an investigation.<ref name="israelis_see_NYT" /> According to Bogert, "[W]e have questions as to whether we've learned everything we need to know".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8256284.stm BBC "Analyst suspended over Nazi hobby" September 15, 2009]</ref> Regarding the suspension, HRW has indicated "This is not a disciplinary measure. Human Rights Watch stands behind Garlasco's research and analysis".<ref name="google.com"/>
===Other responses === Critics of Human Rights Watch have suggested that Garlasco's enthusiasm for Nazi-era badges and uniforms goes beyond historical interest and raises questions Nazi sympathy or anti-Semitism.<ref>[http://www.wbur.org/news/npr/112900014 WBUR]</ref>
[[NGO Monitor]], an Israeli NGO that monitors human rights organisations for perceived political bias, described Garlasco's hobby as "problematic" and "insensitive".<ref name="JP=2009-09-09"/> John Richardson of ''Esquire'' magazine wrote that because Garlasco has criticized Israel for alleged human-rights violations, "NGO Monitor has decided to try to destroy Marc Garlasco — not to argue with him or dispute his statistics, but to destroy him personally."<ref name=Esquire />
[[Antony Lerman]], former director of the [[Institute for Jewish Policy Research]], wrote that Human Rights Watch failed to see Garlasco's hobby "could be used to discredit his role as author of highly critical reports of Israel's military conduct in Gaza". Lerman further wrote that Garlasco working "on reports critical of Hamas and Hezbollah was ignored", concluding that "as another excuse to attack HRW, and deflect attention from its reports' findings, the Garlasco affair was a gift".<ref name=LermanGuardian>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/sep/15/human-rights-gaza-israel ''The Guardian'': Judge Goldstone and the pollution of argument]</ref>
[[Yaron Ezrahi]], a Professor of Political Science at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, said he did not believe that Mr. Garlasco's interest in memorabilia could support allegations of "premeditated bias," though he indicated it may hurt Human Rights Watch's credibility, and that the revelations had "armed the right-wing fanatics" who try to "demonize" anybody who questions the effects of Israeli military operations.<ref name="israelis_see_NYT" /> A group of ten Israeli rights groups also protested that the Israeli government has been attempting to "instill fear and silence or alarm vital organizations" that were engaging in free public discourse.<ref name=NPR>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=112900014&ps=cprs ''NPR'': Rights Analyst Suspended Over Nazi-Era Collection]</ref>
In the ''Christian Science Monitor'', Robert Marquand claimed Garlasco's critics were using him "to distract from or obfuscate findings that war crimes and crimes against humanity may have taken place in Gaza" and that a U.N. report by [[Richard Goldstone]] showed illegal [[white phosphorus]] use consistent with Garlasco's first hand testimony.<ref>[http://features.csmonitor.com/globalnews/2009/09/17/gaza-war-analyst-does-his-nazi-era-collection-indicate-bias/ ''Christian Science Monitor'': Gaza war analyst: Does his Nazi-era collection indicate bias?]</ref>
In ''Nazi scandal hits human rights group'', Katie Engelhart in ''[[Macleans]]'' magazine reported that "For HRW, the timing of the exposé could not be worse. The group has thrown its weight behind the UN-sponsored Goldstone report, which accuses both Israel and the Palestinians of committing war crimes in the Gaza strip earlier this year. Garlasco's actions will surely lead many to question the group's credibility".<ref>[http://www2.macleans.ca/2009/10/01/nazi-scandal-hits-human-rights-group/ Engelhart, K. ''Nazi scandal hits human rights group''], Macleans, October 1, 2009 (retrieved October 15, 2009)</ref>
According to the [[New York Times]], HRW Middle East advisory committee member [[Helena Cobban]] questioned on her blog whether Garlasco's military collecting activities were "something an employer like Human Rights Watch ought to be worried about? After consideration, I say Yes".<ref name="israelis_see_NYT">[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/15/world/middleeast/15nazi.html?hp ''Rights Group Assailed for Analyst’s Nazi Collection''], New York Times, John Schwartz, September 14, 2009</ref> NGO Monitor head [[Gerald M. Steinberg]], a Professor of Political Science at [[Bar Ilan University]], argued that Human Rights Watch's response to the matter was "too little, too late".<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/6194158/Human-Rights-Watch-suspends-researcher-who-collected-Nazi-memorabilia.html ''The Telegraph'' "Human Rights Watch suspends researcher who collected Nazi memorabilia," September 15, 2009]</ref> Cobban says in suspending Garlasco Human Rights Watch is now "in a better position to take part in the public discussion in this country on what our government should be doing with regard to the Goldstone report".<ref name=NPR />
===Aftermath === Emma Daly confirmed in March 2010 that Garlasco resigned from Human Rights Watch in February 2010, and offered no elaboration.<ref name="jpquit"/> A reporter from the ''Times Online'' attempted to contact Garlasco, who wouldn't comment. A friend of Garlasco's indicated he had "in effect" been fired, but had entered into a confidentiality agreement with HRW in which he would be paid for the remainder of his contract if he kept silent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article7076462.ece|title=Nazi scandal engulfs Human Rights Watch|last=Foreman|first=Jonathan|publisher=The Times Online|accessdate=29 March 2010 | location=London | date=2010-03-28}}</ref> [[Gerald M. Steinberg]], in an op-ed in the [[Ottawa Citizen]], wrote that while HRW had promised an investigation, it has not offered any information about it to the public, or addressed the issue of the credibility of Garlasco's reports on Israeli human rights violations.<ref>[https://ottawacitizen.com/story_print.html?id=2679204&sponsor= ''Ottawa Citizen'' ''The sad state of 'human rights' organizations,'']{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Gerald Steinberg, March 14, 2010</ref>
==Bibliography==
===Book=== * ''The Flak Badges of the Luftwaffe and Heer,'' 2008, B&D Publishing LLC.<ref name=guardian_allegations /> 462 pages
===Human Rights Watch reports co-authored by Marc Garlasco===
* ''[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2009/04/14/dying-practice-0 A Dying Practice: Use of Cluster Munitions by Russian and Georgia in August 2008]'' * ''[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2009/03/25/rain-fire Rain of Fire: Israel's Unlawful Use of White Phosphorus in Gaza]'' * ''[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2008/09/08/troops-contact-0 Troops in Contact: Airstrikes and Civilian Deaths in Afghanistan]'' Human Rights Watch, 2008, {{ISBN|1564323625}} * ''[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2008/02/16/flooding-south-lebanon-0 Flooding South Lebanon: Israel's Use of Cluster Munitions in Lebanon in July and August 2006]'' * ''[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2006/07/22/no-blood-no-foul No Blood No Foul": Soldier's Accounts of Detainee Abuse in Iraq]'' * ''[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2005/09/22/leadership-failure-0 Leadership Failure: First Hand Accounts of Torture of Iraqi Detainees by the U.S. Army's 82nd Airborne Division]'' * ''[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2004/10/17/razing-rafah-0 Razing Rafah: Mass Home Demolitions in the Gaza Strip]'' * ''[https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2003/12/11/target-0 Off Target: The Conduct of the War and Civilian Casualties in Iraq]''
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.humanrightswatch.org Human Rights Watch] *''[https://www.hrw.org/en/video/2009/09/10/field-marc-garlasco-2008 In the Field with Marc Garlasco]'', Human Rights Watch (2008) *''[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=89460867 Assessing the Human Cost of Air Strikes in Iraq]'', NPR (April 8, 2008)

page.title: Mary Queen of Scots Got Her Head Chopped Off

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Mary Queen of Scots Got Her Head Chopped Off''''' is a 1987 play by [[Liz Lochhead]]. It explores the relationship between [[Elizabeth I of England]] and [[Mary Queen of Scots|Mary Stuart]]. It is primarily written to be from a female point of view, and is considered to be Lochhead's most successful and critically acclaimed play.<ref name=BBC>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/scotland/arts/writingscotland/learning_journeys/women_writers/liz_lochhead/works.shtml |title= Writing Scotland - Liz Lochhead |publisher=BBC |work=BBC Two |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> According to the [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] website:
:''"[ Lochhead ] has the character of Elizabeth enact masculine types of behaviour (even appearing on stage in men’s clothes) as a means of representing the exclusion of feminine behaviour in the political realm. Mary, by contrast, wields a more conventionally feminine power, exploiting her sexuality and the emotional vulnerability associated with her sex in order to get her own way.''"<ref name=BBC/>
It was first performed by the Communicado Theatre Company at the 1987 [[Edinburgh Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|author=British Council |url=http://literature.britishcouncil.org/liz-lochhead |title=Liz Lochhead | British Council Literature |publisher=Literature.britishcouncil.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> [[Marilyn Imrie#Mary Queen of Scots Got Her Head Chopped Off|Mary Queen of Scots Got Her Head Chopped Off]] was broadcast as a [[radio play]] directed by [[Marilyn Imrie]] by [[BBC Radio 4]] on 11 February 2001.
The [[National Theatre of Scotland]] toured a new production of the play across Scotland in 2009, directed by [[Alison Peebles]] who played Elizabeth in the original production. ''Mary Queen of Scots Got Her Head Chopped Off'' was revived again on stage in 2011, and toured to [[Royal Lyceum Theatre|Lyceum Theatre]], Edinburgh and [[Dundee Rep Theatre]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lyceum.org.uk/webpages/show_info.php?id=1101 |date=25 September 2011 |accessdate=8 September 2013 |title=Mary Queen of Scots Got Her Head Chopped Off |work=www.lyceum.org.uk |publisher= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110925045246/http://www.lyceum.org.uk/webpages/show_info.php?id=1101 |archivedate=25 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thecourier.co.uk/Living/Stage/article/18252/review-mary-queen-of-scots-got-her-head-chopped-off-dundee-rep.html |title=Review: Mary Queen of Scots Got Her Head Chopped Off (Dundee Rep) |publisher=DC Thomson |work=The Courier |date=2011-12-20 |accessdate=2012-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509101726/http://www.thecourier.co.uk/Living/Stage/article/18252/review-mary-queen-of-scots-got-her-head-chopped-off-dundee-rep.html |archivedate=2012-05-09 |df= }}</ref>
:"''Once upon a time, there were twa queens on the wan green island, and the wan green island was split inty twa kingdoms. But no equal kingdoms.''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaltheatrescotland.com/content/default.asp?page=home_MaryQueenofScotsGotHerHeadChoppedOff |title=Mary Queen of Scots Got Her Head Chopped Off |publisher=Nationaltheatrescotland.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2011/sep/22/mary-queen-of-scots-got-review Review] at [[the Guardian]] * [http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/33572/mary-queen-of-scots-got-her-head-chopped-off Review] at [[The Stage]] * [http://digital.nls.uk/scottish-theatre/mary-queen/index.html National Library of Scotland page]

{{COI|date=July 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox magazine | logo = Mishpacha_Magazine_Logo.png | logo_size = | image_file = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | editor = | editor_title = | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | photographer = | category =[[News magazine]] | frequency = Weekly | circulation = 500,000 | publisher = The Mishpacha Group | founder = Eliyahu Paley | founded = 1984 | firstdate = | company = | based = Israel | language = English, Hebrew | website = http://www.mishpacha.com/ | oclc = 57819059 }} '''''Mishpacha''''' ({{lang-he|משפחה}}, "Family") is the flagship [[magazine]] in a weekly magazine package produced by The Mishpacha Group in both English and [[Hebrew]].
==History== The Mishpacha Publishing Group was founded in 1984 with the publication of the Hebrew Mishpacha magazine. Publisher and CEO Eli Paley teamed with Rabbi Moshe Grylak towards the goal of producing a magazine that would serve as a conduit for the exchange of ideas and values between the varying streams within [[Orthodox Judaism|Jewish orthodoxy]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Mishpacha Magazine 10th Anniversary Edition|url=http://www.mishpacha.com/Browse/Article/4122/Mega-Pesach-Issue-5774|publisher=Mishpacha|accessdate=April 22, 2015}}</ref> among them the [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]], [[Haredi Judaism|Yeshivish]], [[Sephardic Haredim|Sephardic]], and [[Modern Orthodox Judaism|Modern Orthodox]] communities. With no other weekly or monthly magazines geared towards Orthodox Jewish readership at that time, Mishpacha quickly gained popularity, in effect launching the Jewish Orthodox magazine industry.<ref>{{cite web|title=God, Jews and the Media: Religion and Israel's Media|url=https://books.google.co.il/books?id=y2o9OjOeys8C&pg=PA74|publisher=Routledge|accessdate=April 22, 2015}}</ref>
First beginning as a monthly, it became a weekly in the beginning of 1991.<ref name=Ilan>{{cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/1.4858736|title=In the Family Way|author=Shahar Ilan|date=Jul 25, 2006|website=[[Haaretz]]|access-date=Jan 22, 2018}}</ref>
The English Mishpacha launched in 2004 with a weekly package including the flagship Mishpacha Magazine and Mishpacha Junior. Mishpacha was the first full-color weekly magazine targeting the Anglo-Orthodox population worldwide, with the standalone children's magazine also serving as an innovation. Family First, introduced to the package in 2005, was also the first of its kind, a full-color weekly magazine by and for Jewish women.<ref>{{cite web|title=Haredi Women's Lit Explodes|url=http://tabletmag.com/jewish-arts-and-culture/books/108710/haredi-womens-lit-explodes|publisher=[[Tablet (magazine)|Tablet]]|accessdate=April 22, 2015}}</ref>
Mishpacha frequently addresses social problems. For example, it has addressed issues such as the ''shababniks'' ([[Haredi]] [[street youth]]) and [[Family violence|violence in the family]]; and has waged a battle against educational institutions’ discrimination against [[Mizrahim]] and the [[Baal teshuva|newly religious]]. But it brings up these issues without mentioning names, so no one will be hurt.<ref name=Ilan/>
Mishpacha's publications, as a rule, do not print photos of women. There have been rare exceptions to this. For example, when Hillary Clinton was running for president against Donald Trump, the magazine chose to print her face, although very obscured by a blue field. This policy is a break from Jewish tradition. Prior to 1990, most Orthodox publications , such as the Jewish Observer of the Agudas Yisroel of America<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://somehowfrum.blogspot.com/2016/11/writers-want-women-whitewashed.html|title=SoMeHoW Frum : Writers Want Women WhiteWashed|last=Frum|first=Somehow|date=2016-11-16|website=SoMeHoW Frum|access-date=2018-01-31}}</ref>, would regularly include photos of women.
Some attribute the significant increase in Haredim joining [[Israel's army]] to Mishpacha as well as [[mental health]] awareness and mental health services access over the past decade amongst Orthodox Jewish populations to the public dialogue stimulated by Mishpacha magazines and other Jewish publications such as [[Ami (magazine)|Ami]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Technology Use in the Religious Communities in Israel: Combining Traditional Society and Advanced Communications |url=http://jrmdc.com/papers/technology-use-israel/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20150422081621/http://jrmdc.com/papers/technology-use-israel/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 22, 2015 |publisher=Journal of Religion, Media and Digital Culture |accessdate=April 22, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Study: Orthodox Jews More Open To Mental Health Counseling, But Needs Remain|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/08/14/study-orthodox-jews-more_n_681898.html|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=April 22, 2015}}</ref> Mishpacha has been banned by many rabbinical leaders<ref>http://www.rationalistjudaism.com/2011/05/gedolims-authority-is-tested.html</ref> <ref>http://www.rationalistjudaism.com/2012/01/gedolims-edicts-and-mishpachah.html</ref> including Rabbi [[Yosef Shalom Elyashiv]].<ref>https://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/headlines-breaking-stories/113410/maran-rav-elyashiv-calls-for-a-ban-against-mishpacha-magazine.html</ref> However, Mishpacha has turned to the rabbinical court of the Haredi community ([[Badatz]]) which forbade harassment of the magazine.<ref name="Ilan" /> [[Haaretz]], the newspaper of Israel's secular left, describes the Hebrew version of ''Mishpacha'' as one of the "most powerful" newspapers in the [[Haredi Judaism|Haredi]] community.<ref name="Chizhik-Goldschmidt">{{cite news|last1=Chizhik-Goldschmidt|first1=Avital|title=Inside the World of ultra-Orthodox Media: Haredi Journalists Tell It Like It Is|url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/jewish-world-features/.premium-1.669916|accessdate=11 August 2015|publisher=Haaretz|date=11 August 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.mishpacha.com}} * {{cite news |author=Shahar Ilan |date=July 12, 2006 |url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/1.1120254 |script-title=he:המשפחה הרביעית |language=he |trans-title=The Fourth Family |newspaper=Haaretz|accessdate=August 21, 2014}}
{{Organized Jewish Life in the United States}}
[[Category:1984 establishments in Israel]] [[Category:Jewish magazines]] [[Category:Israeli magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1984]] [[Category:Media in Jerusalem]] [[Category:News magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]]

'''Ms. Olympia''' is the title given to the winner of the [[female bodybuilding|women's bodybuilding]] portion of [[Joe Weider's Olympia Fitness & Performance Weekend]]—an international [[professional bodybuilding]] competition that was held annually by the [[International Federation of BodyBuilders]] (IFBB). It was first held in 1980, and from 2000 to 2014 it has been held at the same time as the [[Mr. Olympia]] contest as part of the "Olympia Weekend". The 2000 contest also saw the introduction of weight classes. No overall winner was named in 2000, but starting in 2001, a posedown between the two class winners decided the overall title. In 2005, the contest returned to the one open class format. The top overall winners are [[Iris Kyle]] (ten overall and two heavyweight), [[Lenda Murray]] (eight), [[Corinna Everson]] (six), and [[Kim Chizevsky-Nicholls]] (four). In 2014, the final Ms. Olympia competition was held.[http://www.hardbodynews.com/2015/01/qualified-2015-olympia/#sthash.jFbTx57L.dpbs Who is Qualified for the 2015 Olympia? ] == History == ===1980–1989=== In 1980, the first Ms. Olympia (initially known as the "Miss" Olympia) was held with [[Rachel McLish]] winning and becoming the first Ms. Olympia. Rachel was dethroned by [[Ritva Elomaa]] in 1981, but regained the title in 1982. George Snyder lost the rights to the Ms. Olympia in 1982, and after this the contestants were no longer hand-picked, but instead qualified for the Ms. Olympia through placings in lesser contests. As female bodybuilding grew and progressed, the competitors' level of training gradually increased, with most of the competitors in the earliest shows having very little weight training experience, and the sport slowly evolving towards more muscular physiques. This trend started to emerge in 1983, with McLish not competing in the big shows, [[Carla Dunlap]] won the 1983 Ms. Olympia. Dunlap possessed a much more muscular physique than previous Ms. Olympia winners McLish or Elomaa. In 1984, Corinna Everson won the Ms. Olympia title. Everson would go on to win six consecutive Ms. Olympia titles in a row before retiring in 1989 undefeated as a professional, the only woman ever to accomplish this. ===1990–1999=== Normally, competitors must qualify for the Ms. Olympia by achieving certain placings in lesser pro contests. However, the cancellation of the Women's Pro World contest in 1990 left only the Ms. International as a Ms. Olympia qualifier. Consequently, the IFBB decided to open the 1990 Ms. Olympia to all women with pro cards, and a field of thirty competitors entered. This was also the first Ms. Olympia without the incumbent Ms. Olympia champion defending her title. Lenda Murray earned a decisive victory by winning the first Ms. Olympia competition she attended in 1990 and emerging as the successor to Corinna Everson. The 1991 Ms. Olympia was the first to be televised live. Lenda Murray barely edged out [[Bev Francis]], a former Australian powerlifter, by a single point that year. Lenda Murray faced a serious challenge from [[Denise Rutkowski]] in 1993, and some argue that Rutkowski, not Murray, should have won that year. Rutkowski shocked the Ms. Olympia contest entourage and fans by retiring in 1994, just as her career was gaining mainstream popularity and her potential for winning a Ms. Olympia title was high. In the 1996 Ms. Olympia, six-time consecutive Ms. Olympia champion Lenda Murray was dethroned by [[Kim Chizevsky-Nicholls]] (then known as Kim Chizevsky). Chizevsky-Nicholls had previously placed 2nd in the 1995 Ms. Olympia, but her victory came as something of a surprise, since many had regarded Murray as virtually unbeatable. After being defeated by Chizevsky-Nicholls and placing second again in the 1997 Ms. Olympia, Murray retired from bodybuilding. Chizevsky-Nicholls went on to win the 1998 Ms. Olympia, held in [[Prague, Czech Republic]], the first and only time the competition had been held outside the United States. ====1992 Ms. Olympia changes==== In response to the increased size displayed by Murray and Francis at the previous Ms. Olympia, the IFBB made an attempt to "feminize" the sport. The IFBB, led by [[Ben Weider]], had created a series of "femininity" rules—one line in the judging rules said that competitors should not be "too big". The judges’ guide to the competitors stated that they were looking for a feminine, but not emaciated, physique. Advertising in [[Muscle & Fitness]] for the 1992 Ms. Olympia featured Anja Schreiner of Germany prominently, relegating two-time defending champion Murray to a small "also competing" notice. Nevertheless, Murray apparently met the "femininity" requirements, and managed to retain her title; Schreiner finished 6th, and promptly retired from competition. After 1992, the judging rules were rewritten, with the new rules retaining provisions for aesthetics but allowing the contests to be judged as physique contests. Murray went on to win six consecutive Ms. Olympia titles from 1990 to 1995, matching Corinna Everson's record. ==== 1999 Ms. Olympia controversy and retirement ==== The 1999 Ms. Olympia was originally scheduled to be held on October 9 in [[Santa Monica, California]]. However, one month before the scheduled date, the IFBB announced that the contest had been cancelled. The main cause was the withdrawal of promoter [[Jarka Kastnerova]] (who promoted the 1998 contest in Prague) for financial reasons, including a low number of advance ticket sales for the 1999 event. The backlash following the announcement led to a flurry of activity, with the contest being rescheduled as part of the Women's Extravaganza (promoted by Kenny Kassel and Bob Bonham) in [[Secaucus, New Jersey]] on 2 October. Last minute sponsorship came from several sources, most significantly in the form of $50,000 from Flex magazine. Amid all the turmoil, Kim Chizevsky-Nicholls won her fourth consecutive Ms. Olympia title. Also notable about the 1999 Ms. Olympia was that this was the first Ms. Olympia Iris Kyle competed in. However, after the 1999 Ms. Olympia, Kim Chizevsky-Nicholls retired from bodybuilding and began competing in fitness and figure competitions in 2001. === 2000–2005 === The 2001 Ms. Olympia featured a "surprise" win from [[Juliette Bergmann]] who returned to competition after not competing since 1989. Entering the Olympia as a lightweight, she defeated heavyweight winner [[Iris Kyle]] for the overall title. In the five years that the Ms. Olympia was contested in multiple weight classes, this was the only time that the lightweight winner took the overall title. After five-year absence, six-time Olympia winner Lenda Murray returned to the 2002 Ms. Olympia, with Bergmann won lightweight and Murray winning heavyweight and overall. Murray went on to win both the heavyweight and overall in the 2002 and 2003 Ms. Olympia. Murray was for the second time in her career was dethroned of her Ms. Olympia title by Iris Kyle in 2004, who won the heavyweight and overall. After her 2004 Ms. Olympia defeat, Murray, retired from bodybuilding. ==== 2000 Ms. Olympia changes ==== The IFBB introduced several changes to Ms. Olympia in 2000. The first change was that Ms. Olympia contest would no longer be held as a separate contest, instead became part of the "Olympia Weekend" in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] and held the day before the men’s show. The second change was when heavyweight and lightweight classes where added. The third change was the new judging guidelines for presentations were introduced. A letter to the competitors from Jim Manion (chairman of the Professional Judges Committee) stated that women would be judged on healthy appearance, face, makeup, and skin tone. The criteria given in Manion's letter included the statement "symmetry, presentation, separations, and muscularity BUT NOT TO THE EXTREME!" The 2000 Ms. Olympia is the only Ms. Olympia with no overall winner, with Andrulla Blanchette winning lightweight class and Valentina Chepiga winning heavyweight class. ==== 2005 Ms. Olympia changes ==== The IFBB introduced the so-called '20 percent rule', requesting "that female athletes in Bodybuilding, Fitness and Figure decrease the amount of muscularity by a factor of 20%". The memo stated that the request "applies to those female athletes whose physiques require the decrease". Another change added to the 2005 Ms. Olympia, was the abandonment of the weight class system adopted in 2000. In 2005 Ms. Olympia, Iris Kyle was dethroned by [[Yaxeni Oriquen-Garcia]]. === 2006–2014 === Iris Kyle reclaimed her Ms. Olympia title in 2006. Iris Kyle has gone on to win nine consecutive Ms. Olympia's in a row from 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, and 2014. With ten overall wins, Kyle has won more Olympia titles, male or female, than any other bodybuilder, and announced her retirement right after winning the title in 2014, which was when the final Ms. Olympia competition was held. == Winners == {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center;" ! revision.text:
'''Mt. Carmel''' is a Jewish cemetery in the [[Wissinoming, Philadelphia|Wissinoming]] neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It was established in the mid-1800s.<ref name=FarrToppled>{{cite news|last1=Farr|first1=Stephanie|title='Beyond belief': 75-100 headstones toppled at Jewish cemetery|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/Cops-Report-of-vandalism-at-Jewish-cemetery.html|accessdate=27 February 2017|website=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=26 February 2017}}</ref>
== Desecration ==
*The cemetery was desecrated in October 1982 by semi-literate vandals who knocked about 100 headstones over, left empty beer bottles, and marked a headstone with two swastikas and "Hile Hitler"(sic).<ref name=FarrToppled/>
[[File:Wave of Anti Semitic Threats Puts US Jewish Community on Edge.webmhd.webm|thumb|thumbtime=00:02|right|"Wave of Anti Semitic Threats Puts US Jewish Community on Edge" news report from [[Voice of America]] March 23, 2017]] *The cemetery was desecrated by vandals in February 2017.<ref name=FarrToppled/><ref name="EllisVandalized">{{cite news|last1=Ellis|first1=Ralph|title=Jewish cemetery in Philadelphia vandalized; 2nd incident in a week|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/26/us/jewish-cemetery-vandalism-philadelphia/|accessdate=27 February 2017|publisher=CNN|date=27 February 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Cemeteries in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Jewish cemeteries in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Cemetery vandalism and desecration]] [[Category:21st-century attacks on synagogues and Jewish communal organizations]]

{{expand Russian|date=July 2018}} The '''parade of sovereignties''' ({{lang-ru|Парад суверенитетов}}, Parad suverenitetov) was a series of declarations of [[sovereignty]] of various degree by the [[Republics of the Soviet Union|constituents]] of the [[Soviet Union]] in late 1980s - early 1990s. These declarations stated the priority of the constituent republic power within its territory over the central power, which have led to the [[War of Laws]] between the center and the republics. The process followed the loosened power grip of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] as a result of ''[[demokratizatsiya (Soviet Union)|demokratizatsiya ]]'' policy of the ''[[perestroika]]'' period of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]. Despite the efforts of Gorbachev to preserve the union under a new treaty in the form of the [[Union of Sovereign States]], soon afterwards many constituents declared their full independence, and the process resulted in the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]].<ref>''The Revenge of the Past: Nationalism, Revolution, and the Collapse of the Soviet Union'', Ronald Grigor Suny, Stanford University Press, 1993, {{ISBN|0-8047-2247-1}} Retrieved on 2009-04-25 </ref>
The first region to declare independence was the [[Nakhichevan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]] (January 19, 1990; however [[Heydar Aliyev]], the leader of [[Azerbaijan SSR]], having roots in [[Nakhchivan (city)|Nakhchivan]], managed to keep Nakhchivan Republic within Azerbaijan).<ref>[https://www.znak.com/2017-01-20/v_eti_dni_v_1990_godu_s_vosstaniya_v_azerbaydzhane_nachalsya_yuridicheskiy_razval_sovetskogo_soyuza "Крах большевистской империи: как гласность «довела» СССР"], ''Znak'', January 20, 2017</ref>
The first top-level [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet republic]] to declare independence was [[Estonian SSR]] (November 16, 1988: [[Estonian Sovereignty Declaration]], March 30, 1990: decree on the transition to the restoration of the Estonian statehood,<ref> {{wikisourcelang-inline|ru|Постановление ВС ЭССР от 30.03.1990}}</ref> May 8, 1990: Law on the State Symbols, which declared the independence <ref>{{wikisourcelang-inline|ru|Закон ЭССР от 08.05.1990 О символике Эстонии}}</ref>, August 20, 1991: Law of the [[Estonian restoration of Independence]]).
This massive [[secession]]ist event has served as a testbench for various theories of secession.<ref>Henry E. Hale, "The Parade of Sovereignties: Testing Theories of Secession in the Soviet Setting", British Journal of Political ScienceVol. 30, No. 1, 2000, pp. 31-56</ref> <ref>Emizet F. Kisangani, Vicki L. Hesli, "The Disposition to Secede: An Analysis of the Soviet Case", ''Comparative Political Studies'' vol. 27, January 1995, {{doi|10.1177/0010414095027004002}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Dissolution of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Secession]] [[Category:Perestroika]]
